description:
Incredible service by Matthew and had wonderful recommendations for the food and drinks. I really appreciated his honesty and happy he was working with our indecisiveness. 

Definitely will come back again and the food was very very tastey.
author: Charly M.

description:
This place is so delicious, the first time I had the food was through Caviar. I went to the actual location and had a wonderful time. 

I love the Chef's special cubanos, they are always so amazing!
author: Kristina C.

description:
I live pretty close to this place, so I was pretty excited to finally get to try it out! This place is pretty aesthetic and quite a small place, so I was worried we wouldn't be able to get a seat but we came a bit late - around 1pm so we were easily able to find seats. 

I ordered the Chef's Cubano which is a monthly special where some of the proceeds go to a charity. This month's sandwich was an asian-fusion inspired cuban sandwich with crispy pork belly, coleslaw, asian vinaigrette and more. This sandwich was super bomb and everybody who tried it loved it.

The other things on the menu were kind of mediocre. My friend had the pollo bowl and they said the chicken was kind of dry and wasn't the best. The El Cubano, which is the standard cuban sandwich is definitely better than other cuban sandwiches I've tried but doesn't blow my mind, but it's a decent sandwich if you're craving it.

All in all, I gave 4 stars because of the excellent Chef's Cubano and I'd definitely come back to try the El Cubano and some of the other menu items because they seem pretty promising.
author: Christopher L.

description: The Cuban-style sandwiches in the casual, bright setting of this little restaurant in the Mission are creative, chef-driven, and delicious! The Gloria sandwich came on pressed Cuban bread with two slices of crispy deep-fried eggplant, a delicious coconut slaw, creamy avocado, and a wonderfully herbal green sauce. We also had the Chef's Cubano, which on my visit was Preeti Mistry's Indian-inspired "Vindalated Cubano" sandwich with juicy vindaloo pork, curry leaf mustard, melted Swiss, and apple fennel turmeric slaw. The flavor fest of spices, the crunch from the slaw, and the tenderness of the pork on the crispy toasted bread was the perfect combination, and such an interesting take on the traditional Cubano! Don't expect anything too fancy here, but do come for the creative flavors and relaxed atmosphere.
author: David K.

description:
Tried the Cuban sandwich, and it's the same broken formula. I really wanted this place to be Cuban, but it is not.
Looks like they got a following, and that is fine with me. I'd rather have a functioning business in my neighborhood than a closed storefront. I may give this place one last shot, but I'm not hopeful it will ever be legit Cuban food.
author: J S.

description:
My friends suggested this restaurant for a Sunday lunch, and I was curious to check it out since I've walked by it a couple times. It looks like one of those places people go to simply for Instagram. I was thinking "Oh yeesh, we gonna pay $25 for some avocado on gluten free bread, take a photo next to some some air plants, and then call it an IG day". 

I may need to lay off the gluten, but I FOSHO need to lay off the hipster sarcasm. Because Media Noche is good. Yes, it is quintessential social media material with air plants, clean aesthetic, and pretty patterned tiled floors. But the food is also good. So I'm in, folks. 

We tried the salads- one with roasted squash and one with lechon. The greens are fresh and the flavors are good. We also tried the Media Noche Cubano, which the waitress said was one of the most popular sandwiches. I was feeling the Cubano with the meat, cheese, pickle, mmhmm. I'll take it. 

I would come back here. The design is light and airy, and... oh gosh, I'm sounding like a hipster now. Imma peace out.
author: Joanna L.

description:
Had high expectations for this place. It was good, but not great, and extremely hipster. Over $50 for lunch for 3 people (3 dishes and empanadas.) 

Service: 3 stars. Not bad, not overly friendly or helpful. 
Aesthetic: bright, new, colorful, extremely hipster.

Food: Get a sandwich. The bowl just wasn't the same and not worth the price at all. It was something you could almost make at home. I liked my Media Noche sandwich, but the pork was a tad bit salty and dry. The Celia is fried chicken with avocado on toasted brioche and was the highlight. The best dish, however, was the empanadas--2 for $10 I think, and you can mix-and-match. We got 2 spiced beef and it came with green sauce and was *chef kisses fingers* just fireworks in our mouths. 

TL;DR: come for the empanadas and maybe the Celia sandwich.
author: Lizzie S.

description:
Great lunch spot! Cuban-inspired fare and I was really excited to see the tile work (I visited Cuba in 2016 and loved all the cool tiles). 

Great service and casual setting. Order at the counter and food is brought to you. Some outdoor seating and all seating inside is communal or counter. 

We almost went to Souvla but saw this place on the way. It's VERY similar to Souvla in terms of aesthetic (even down to the bowls) and theme (sandwiches and salads). It's sort of like a Cuban Souvla. 

We got empanadas, plantain chips, ceviche and a salad with pork. Everything was a few dollars too expensive tbh. I thought everything was delicious-ceviche has a nice kick to it and the salad was flavorful. Pork in the salad was slow cooked and tender. The size of the large salad is *huge* and I got two meals out of it.

Good option when in the area for a quick bite but this is definitely the *new* (aka gentrifying) Mission. Lots of cheap local food abounds in the area at taquerias and pappuserias. As with all businesses in the rapidly changing Mission, I hope they train and hire black and brown people and have them in the front of the house/at the register as well as cooking in the back or cleaning. I didn't see a diverse staff in the front when I went so that's an area for improvement.

Overall, yummy if pricey Cuban-inspired food in the Mission with cute interior. Worth a try.
author: Semuteh F.

description: Everything in this place is so nice, food, decoration and service. Can't wait to visit again soon. Ceviche, Guava and lime water was delicious.
author: Sol L.

description:
As soon as I stepped into the small but spacious blue shop, I was in love with the calming teal-blue, rustic decor that makes me feel like I'm somewhere out of the country on vacation. The tables were generously spaced out, which was nice and I liked that it wasn't too crowded during prime dinner time on the weekday night I went.

The shop is more casual (but with great ambiance), where you go up to the counter to order first before taking a number card back to your table. The cashier was super nice and recommended certain items to us since we took a while to decide on the side. Five stars for sure for restaurant ambiance and service!

I got the Midnight Mimosa and Media Noche Sandwich, and my friend got the Mexican Coke (in a retro glass) and the Cuban Sandwich. The mimosa was amazing and really nice to sip on casually while chatting, although it didn't necessarily go that well with the sandwich. The pork in my sandwich was a bit too dry and too salty to me, although the condiments complimented the overall sandwich pretty well. Media Noche was a bit underwhelming for me, as I was expecting a more Latin America flavor to the sandwich and was a bit disappointed that it was more American in taste. Portion size was perfect to finish in one sitting and was standard for the city's price and definitely not too expensive for a casual dinner. I would give the mimosa a five star and the sandwich a three star.

Overall, I would come back for Happy Hour to just drink, although I wouldn't mind giving their other food menu items a chance as well.
author: Victoria W.

description:
I stopped by here for lunch one day and got the El Cubano sandwich.  The sandwich was tasty.  It had a delicious pork shoulder with nicely toasted bread.  It was a warm day, so I decided to also get the mi abuelita favorita moon bar.  This was a chocolate ice cream bar with guava cheese cake.  The guava cheese cake filling definitely intrigued me, but I didn't notice much of the flavor it in the bar.

As I arrived, the place seemed relatively quiet but quickly got busy and a bit cramped.  I also thought it was a bit pricey for just a sandwich and ice cream bar.  Overall, I really enjoyed my experience here and would return to get another sandwich.
author: Mitch T.

description:
My brother recommended Media Noche to me and I'm glad he did as I probably would have never found this restaurant myself. In the mission serving up Cuban food yumminess. The staff are super friendly and welcoming- especially Michael. My brother ordered the Celia which is his favorite thing on the menu. My mom ordered the Lechon Asada Bowl kids style (for a smaller portion). I ordered the Chef's Cubano which was Lamb, Pickles, Garlic, Mint Yogurt, Feta and Hot Sauce. Delicious. 
Definitely will be coming back to try their Empanadas and Happy Hour!
author: Lauryn H.

description: Sorry to say it has taken a bit for me to review this wonderful place - but that does not mean I don't dream of their sandwiches and coconut slaw all the time! Can I also say it is incredibly adorable as well? I could move into this place today and be perfectly happy (especially if the chef stayed on and cooked all of my meals). Their Cubanos are to do die for - I love the Celia, with its lightly fried chicken, avocado and slaw - I can barely finish it (but, I mean, c'mon - I DO!). The El Cubano is equally delicious and the Chef's Cubano, which changes regularly, is always a good choice. Add to that a glass or wine, sangria, beer, or a mimosa and you're set. I also adore their Iced Cafe Con Leche, which packs a considerable caffeine punch. Everyone who works at this wonderful place in the Mission is sweet and friendly, there are a few outside tables, it's just heaven! Go - Go - Go - you will not regret it!
author: Lisa W.

description:
GET THE EMPANADAS! That is all you need to know. I ordered the spicy beef one and wow it was delicious.  I don't know exactly what the green sauce is, but dip your empanadas in it! I would definitely go back right now if I could just to get the empanadas again.

I also ordered the croquetas, but they seemed so small for $9, but I guess that is San Francisco for you. They were good, but just not worth the price in my opinion. If they were a little bigger, or there were a few more pieces, then it would be worth purchasing again. 

The decor in the restaurant is so pretty and so is the bathroom (if you end up having to go). 

Just come here for the empanadas and other foods you want to try. I would definitely come back to try other things.
author: Allyson L.

description:
Media Noche is a super cute spot in SF that is lined with plants and pastels! It caught my eye because it was cuisine I don't get to eat much of and the interior looked inviting.

I went on a Saturday around brunch time and it was quite busy, but I was able to find 2 seats at the bar area. I ordered the Ropa Vieja bowl. It was good, definitely filling and slightly on the generous side portion-wise. So with good food and a pretty interior, what could go wrong?

The ONLY thing about Media Noche is the pricing - my bowl came out to around $17 some how which I thought was a bit ridiculous. I didn't expect it to be that much, but eh, I guess it is SF after all.

Make sure you drink lots and venture into the bathroom...because it has BANANA ART ON IT. BANANA ART I TELL YOU!
author: Alice A.

description:
If you want phenomenal fresh delivery (through Caviar) - get Media Noche.

An adorable and beautifully decorated Cuban themed spot in the Mission - Media Noche has a slew of passionate followers - who rave about their delicious pressed sandwiches and bowls.

I ordered their Pobrecito bowl tonight and was blown away. The Pobrecito bowl consists of roasted seasonal butternut squash and pepitas in a fragrant spicy mojo sauce. It's accompanied by moist white rice, a dreamy coconut slaw (shredded cabbage, bell pepper, toasted coconut, cilantro, and lime) and black beans. Definitely be sure to add a side of their famous tangy green sauce too.

In addition to their big portioned main dishes - Media Noche boasts exceptional sides. I'm partial to their plantain chips, which come paired with their magical green sauce.  If you have any avocado at home - they are ideal for dipping into homemade guacamole. 

If you're looking for a mellow Netflix night and want to order in food that is both flavorful and healthy - try Media Noche.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Great food! 

I popped in here on a whim after going to another restaurant that closed. I was pleasantly surprised.

I had the small verde salad which was delicious! Very refreshing, light, and tangy. I loved the pepitas, too.

For the main I had the vegetarian bowl (with pumpkin). The rice and beans were amazing and the coconut slaw was good but not my favorite. It tastes like they use the dried coconut which I am not a fan of. The pumpkin was ok, it didn't knock my socks off. Maybe it was just the mood I was in that day but I would have been happy with just the salad and rice and beans. 

It gets busy quick but we got lucky and got there just before the rush. The seating is communal unless you have enough people to fill the table.

Affordable and tasty. I enjoyed it.
author: Jess A.

description:
Thanks to my Bestest for taking me here, I've been wanting to go here and it was very close to my favorite ice cream shop Garden Creamery. 

This place was decorated so cute and IG worthy. Love the lighting for this restaurant. 

We ordered the following:

- Picadillo Empanadas ($9) - spiced ground beef and green sauce. 

- Celia ($12.50) - island fried chicken sandwich with coconut slaw, avocado, and green sauce. 

- Agua Fresca Del Dia ($4.50) - quava flavor of the day. 

A perfect light snack to hold us over before our dinner.
author: Owie N.

description:
I love Media noche because it's super trendy and a great place to hang with friends! Also, they take classic Cuban specialties and put their own modern spin with it. My big problem with Media Noche is 1. it attracts people that take obnoxious photos in their banana bathroom for maybe 10-15 minutes or spend the same amount of time taking pictures of their shoes with the floor and 2. The price for what it is - especially their Cubano Sandwiches and bowls - is pretty outrageous. 

I got a Ropa Vieja bowl (pretty small portion) with added avocado ($19) and a drink and this came up to about $26. I get it..It's San Francisco and its trendy, but I was still hungry right afterwards and there was nothing special about it. Besides that, their cubano sandwiches such as the el cubano is really good and I enjoy the ceviche - great amount of heat and goes well with the plantane chips. The staff is also really super nice and they have a great selection of alcoholic drinks and desserts. For the food and price, this isn't the best place in the Mission, but it is good if you are coming for a drink and light bites.
author: Eric Joseph D.

description: Food was bland & unauthentic--yet overpriced. ($30 for a Cubano & a side empanadas?). I've been blessed to have *real* Cuban food & Media Noche is not it. Appears Mission Local thought the same thing, pointing out Media Noche is another outcome of gentrification: https://missionlocal.org/2018/10/the-fried-chicken-sandwich-showdown-visits-media-noche/. On top of this, the staff was cold & unfriendly & come to find out--the server is co-owner of this establishment. Not coming back here again. Shoulda stuck w Natives' go-to for Cuban food, est 1974(!) in the Mission: https://www.frutilandiasf.com/about-us. Now that's real Cuban food w warm service that makes you feel home.
author: Jacqueline R.

description:
[62/100]

If you like fresh coconut, please try this place! 

The thought of coconut being in a savory dish never crossed my mind but after having their Gloria Cubano, I need to start cooking with coconut more! 

Crispy eggplant, a coconut slaw and avocado pressed between toasty bread with green sauce, i'm getting bummed that there isn't a Media Noche here in Los Angeles. Their portion is generous and all the flavors just work! 

I haven't had Cuban food too many times but I'm officially a fan! 

The restaurant is on the corner of the block and you can't miss it! It is this cute tiffany blue color with spacious sitting. I visited on a hot day in SF so I appreciated the coolness of this place. It is also simple which I enjoyed because it wasn't overwhelming! 

I also had a side of their plantain chips, delicious! 

Pros:
- Vegetarian friendly.
- Walking distance from shopping. 
- Great customer service!
- Eclectic modern decor. 
- Super delicious food!

Cons:
- Pricy
author: Patricia D.

description:
There's no shortage of good eats in the Mission, but few Cuban places. Thankfully, there's Media Noche.

A brightly painted teal storefront, you can't miss it on 19th. The decor is really well done and it's got a nice vibe so if you have the time (and can snag a table) stay and eat in. There's a variety of seating options whether you're with a group or eating for one, enjoy eating outside or want to stay warm in.

First timers - grab and menu and look over it entirely before stepping up to the register to order. People may come for the sandwiches but there's a number of options and I'd actually recommend one of the bowls and the sides. We got El Cubano and felt it was on the dry side. However, we also got the green salad (small, it's plenty for two as a side), and the Croquetas. Both solid picks.

Guava and cheesecake is one of my favorite combos so I really wanted to try the Mi Abuelita Favorita (Guava Cheesecake) Moonbar but was too full this trip. Not nearly enough places do guava desserts. Will need to make a special stop for it next time.
author: Lindsey C.

description:
Had to drop by since I was in Mission District exploring! Was recommended by a friend to see it if I was ever in the area. 

The place had a really nice vibe to it and the service was great. 

Ended up getting the El Cubano and beef empanadas. I personally though everything was a little expensive given the portion size. It tasted great, but I did wish I had a little more. They definitely did live up to hype regarding the taste. 

Would for sure recommend it to anyone if they were looking to get Cuban food in the area, but it sure can be a little pricey.
author: Timothy D.

description:
I've had my fair share of great Cuban sandwiches having lived in NYC for many years with a few vacations to Miami sprinkled in.  I was not impressed by their Cuban sandwich at all; felt mainly like a pulled pork panini with a few light Cuban accents.  However, everything else was nice, so I guess I can round up to an A-OK of 3-stars.

Mariquitas: Really liked these.  Nice and long.  Super crispy.  And the green sauce was such a refreshing pairing; loved the heavy cilantro undercurrents.

El Cubano: Ugh, not a fan.  The bread was toasted too much so that it was burnt more than a bit.  The ham to pulled pork ratio was totally slanted in favor of the pulled pork.  I get that they're proud of the pulled pork for being made in-house, but a strong ham presence is essential to the sandwich balance.  Also, not enough pickles.  A few little thinly sliced circles as opposed to a thick cut which should cover most of the sandwich.

Guava & Lime Agua Fresca: Big fan of guava, so right up my alley.  Managed to be heavy on the guava without feeling too grainy.
author: Adam B.

description:
Media Noche is a really good place to eat.  It also has a cool vibe to it.  Glad that I found this and highly recommend.  Go take a look at the wall paper in the bathroom.  

Food -   We started off with empanadas and mariquitas.   Both were very good.  The green sauce that came with the empanadas was top notch.  Good flavor with a nice burn.   For my main I had the lechon Asado Bowl.   Again the flavor and quality was spot on.   

Service -   You order from the counter and they deliver to the table.   The staff was friendly and personable.   

Atmosphere -   Clean look to the place.  White subway tiles with a modern look.   

Really good experience and food was on point.   I recommend this place to everyone.
author: Rob D.

description:
Such an soothing calming place. My local friends knew of this place since our first choice was closed. Once you enter you proceed to the counter and place your order and pay. Their menu is very condensed so the options are are few. It takes up one page. 
I went with a Cuban sandwich, which I admit at first I was skeptical to try. But, once I bit into it, my mind was changed.  If I ever get back to the bay area, this place assuming still in biz will be a stop of mine. I would recommend it to anyone traveling here. It is pricey like much of SF.
author: Scott H.

description:
I was almost certain I had already reviewed this place. Let me start off by saying that I was born and raised in Cuba, so I'm clearly well versed in its cuisine.

The grub at Media Noche, while not "authentic" by any means, is a beautiful and well-executed spin off on my motherland's delicious food. Everything that we ordered here was scrumptious, and both me and my husband (also Cuban) really enjoyed lunching here. The space is small and finding a seat may be a bit difficult due to this joint's popularity, but it is so worth it. They have a highly coveted seating area outside which is our personal favorite.

Food highlights: Cubano sandwich, empanadas, croquetas, and the mariquitas. Nice touch on the little dipping sauces and the service was on point. Looking forward to returning when my in-laws come to visit us from Miami.
author: Joanna R.

description:
The decor and entire spot is cute. Service is quick and very friendly!

Being Cuban, I was hoping for an explosion of garlic flavors in my arroz congri and meats. While the bowls were pretty and the portions good, I didn't have that explosion of flavor I was hoping for.

My husband did enjoy his bowl! I won't be back only because I didn't like the flavors for the price. That being said, I know I'm picky when it comes to Cuban food so I would recommend you all check it out for yourself! It was a full house when we went so they are clearly doing something right!
author: Carina M.

description:
It was a very cute place, I enjoyed the vibe. As other yelpers' tips, we got basic snacks - plantain chips, empanadas
 and for main dish - chicken bowl, media noche and two glasses of sangria. Every dish was good but the sandwich - media noche was too salty for me. But the price.. over 80 dollars for two people..this is why I don't eat out in SF.
author: Jiwon H.

description: Went here tonight for dinner with a friend around 8, and it was great! The food came out super quickly and there was plenty of seating. We both ordered the verde bowl with roasted vegetables, and the portion was huge! They didn't skimp on the vegetables or the avocado either, which we appreciated! I'm a souvla lover, and I feel like this was the souvla of Latin American food, and it may compete with souvla as my favorite fast casual meal in the city! I'll definitely be back!
author: Sonia S.

description:
Great Cuban food and that's coming from my husband who grew up on homemade Cuban food in Miami. Keep in mind this isn't your grandmas food, it's a lighter and modern take on classic dishes. We had the guava pastelitos, ropa vieja bowl, chicken bowl, picadillo empanadas, and Cuban sandwich. My daughter commented that the chicken was fresh and tender. The pork in the Cuban sandwich was super tasty and not overly salty. 

Only comment that would take this down to 4 stars is the counter service, the young lady taking orders was a little aloof and not friendly. Maybe it was an off day but good service and personal recommendations make a difference when you have new customers visiting the restaurant.
author: Laniey F.

description:
I really wanted to love this place since we don't have enough Cuban food in the city. The food was fine but I've had better AND cheaper. I know this is SF so it's not apples to apples. Or should I say manzanas to manzanas? But then the Mission is lined with taquerias that are able to charge a lot less.

Anyway, if you ever are in SoCal stop by Porto's and get the Cubano sandwich for only $6. The sandwich even comes with plantain chips. The sandwich here was $12.50 and the chips were $5.50 and both were not as good as Porto's.

I do have to say the staff is friendly though.
author: Andy W.

description:
I've been eyeing this place since I moved back to SF. I saw it across the street when I was waiting in line for boba guys, but I was too shy to check it out. After a day in DP with some friends, and with some wine in my system, I was like... hey, maybe I can finally check out Media Noche, and I did. 

[1] El Cubano - roasted pork shoulder, smoked ham, swiss, house pickles, and mustard. They got me at Cubano, pickles, and mustard. This was my favorite of the dishes I tried that night. Bread was awesome, pork was moist and well seasoned, house pickles and mustard were of course awesome. Even my left-overs tasted good after a quick zap in the oven! 

[2] Celia - island fried chicken, coconut slaw, avocado, famous green sauce. My friends know I'm a sucker for fried chicken, so we tried this dish and it was pretty good. I'm more a savory fanatic, so the coconut slaw didn't entice me as much. However, my friend thoroughly enjoyed this one. 

[3] Picadillo empanadas - spiced ground beef, famous green sauce. Not gonna lie, the famous green sauce is pretty damn good, it goes great on everything! The empanadas on the other hand were just a-ok, I probably wouldn't order this one again.

We didn't get a chance to try any of the drinks, because we were already pretty tossed... so we will save that for next time. Great spot, will visit again!
author: Elaine N.

description:
Five stars just for the service alone! I came to this restaurant for a friend's bday dinner, and even if they don't take reservations, we found space at the restaurant fairly easily. The manager, Matthew, was incredibly kind and attentive to our party even though we sat outside. He even gave us some freebies (plantain chips, an extra carafe of sangria) and made us feel incredibly welcome.

We had the chicken and eggplant cubanos, as well as the pollo bowl. The food was amazingly spiced and tasty, and I can't wait to come back to this adorable place.
author: Caroline Y.

description: First and best Cubano I've had! The spirit of Cuba is very prevalent in the adorable restaurant. Check out the banana wall in the restaurant. The decor was spectacular chosen with an artist's mind. Great interior decor.
author: Lisa F.

description: Came here for a late lunch at around 3pm on a Saturday. They have great ceviche (it was shrimp on the day I dined) that comes with plantain chips, and the el cubano was on point! Fast service and casual atmosphere. I would come back even for the ceviche alone.
author: Christina W.

description:
The Mission isn't as known for its Cuban cuisine as it is for its Mexican cuisine, but this spot did not disappoint! I got the Cubano sandwich. Flavor was solid-- pork was tender and ham wasn't cheap. But the portion size was a little small. I understand that the sandwich is like a panini of sorts (in terms of how the bread is pressed), but I've had other Cubano sandwiches (in Miami) where the pork is busting from the seams!! 

Then again SF is not Miami and I may be a bit rough here. Overall, great place-- check em out. Also, I heard the ceviche was good..
author: Vasiliy M.

description: The El Cubano was so good!!!! And the Plantains were amazing! Wife had the Cecilia and she loved it! Great spot definitely somewhere to go when your in town!!!
author: Chris R.

description:
Let me preface this review that I only had the sangria, but it was AMAZING! The service was great - drinks were fairly priced, and free water to give you a break from your walk to around the district. 
Check out the photos of the beautiful decor pieces! For a cultural decor lover, this place is a gem!
author: Jonna Leanne P.

description:
High 3 stars.

We were sad to see radish go and curious to see what this new Cuban place offers. It's a cute spot (flamingos painted on the exterior and on a neon sign inside. Banana print wallpaper in the bathroom), the food was good but did not astound us. 

THE WAIT: Probably the bets part - none on a Saturday at 11:45am. There never seems to be a wait. We got a table outside as well to sit with my dog.

THE COST: $54.20 total for 1 starter, 2 entrees, and 2 desserts.

SNACKS
* Picadillo Empanadas ($9) - 4 stars
Juicy ground beef filling, love the green sauce, thick buttery crust. 

ENSALADAS
* Roja Ensalada ($6 small, plus $5 for lechon) - 3.5 stars
Meat is great. Salad dressing had lemon flavor that was too overwhelming. 

CUBANOS
* Celia (fried chicken cubano, $12.50) - 3 stars
Coconut slaw was good, but chicken & bread a bit dry. 

MOON BARS
* Cafe Con Leche ($5) - 4 stars
Good if you like coffee ice cream. Texture of shell & ice cream spot on! 

* Mi Abuela ($5) - 4 stars
The guava is super interesting with dark chocolate & comes in as an aftertaste.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Came here for lunch and got the pollo bowl, cecilia sandwich and bean and cheese empanadas!
+ first of all the aesthetics of this place set the tone..from the floors to the colors and signs ans even the BATHROOM this place is gorgeous and well designed
+ food came out quickly
+ lots of seating (indoor and outdoor), counter seating inside mainly
+ friendly service
+ food was warm and fresh tasting! Not extraordinary but pretty good...
+ big portions for the bowl
+ Famous GREEN SAUCE is very good MUST TRY!  Comes with the empanadas and is also available inside as a condiment!
+ flamingo wall outside is so cute for pics!! 

- its expensive but im also paying for the ambience and good wages so its ok

Fyi I don't eat pork but the cubano sandwich seems to be popular here!
author: Mahima D.

description:
I'm on the fence about placed that partially exist/are flocked to for their instagramibility (sp?) but I think there's some (delicious) substance behind Media Noche so I'm cool with it. 

I DIDN'T get the Cuban. So that's where my experience may differ from the majority of people who come here. 

I DID get the Ceviche (LOVED it), the Verde Salad (thought it was great), and the "Gloria", a crispy eggplant sandwich (fantastic). Sangria from the business across the street was also great, though not big pour with the amount of ice in the small glass. Based on what I had- 5 stars. 

The counter service could have been friendlier and a tad less snarky. There were like 8 people in line from 2 different directions and no sign indicating where it starts/ends so people just kept lining up in different areas, there were legit tributaries forming and it got a little tense and awkward and I think some basic signage would help avoid that and make people feel a little more comfortable with their full experience at Media Noche.  

Overall really enjoyed it and will definitely be back and will keep my fingers crossed for a slow day so as to avoid any line confusion/altercations.
author: Candice G.

description:
Food : 2/5
Service: 3/5
Ambiance: 4/5
Overall: can't say I'd be back.  The food is small in portion size and wasn't spectacular in flavor.

The extended review...

Food:

Ceiveche - this consisted of shrimp and I believe calamari.  Tiny portion and nothing particularly special about it.

Ropa vieja bowl - I was super excited to taste this as I haven't found a place in the Bay Area that serves this dish.  I actually made some of my own in a crockpot and it was more flavorful than this dish.

Service: ok service but they weren't really helpful with giving suggestions on the food itself.  

Ambiance: cool spot and good vibe
author: Spencer Q.

description: Only ever had their empanadas but I LOVE them. The green sauce is crack and I keep coming back even though they are overpriced. When visiting, don't miss the bathroom. That room is cray.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Been craving this ever since having my first meal there this past weekend. BOMB Cubans & also really good snacks & sides. Too Yummy!!!
author: Matt M.

description:
Dinner review. 

Cubano (Media noche) - 3/5 - Needs more cheese
Croqueta - 3/5
Plantain chips - 3/5
Empanadas - 3/5
Moon pie (guava) - 4/5

Overall, "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description:
I have a newfound obsession for empanadas and flamingos. All thanks to Media Noche.

This new, fast-casual, cuban food counter should be on everyone's list. Why? Because.

ZE VIBE! Everything checks off - an ornate flamingo wall mural outside, beautiful tile floors inside, and funky banana walls in the bathroom. Every inch of this place is Instagram-worthy so make sure your battery is fully charged, you will be very much compelled to snap pictures in here like nobody's business.

ZE FOOD! The food here is equally as impressive as their decor. YOU MUST GET the El Cubano Sandwich, with a side of picadillo empanadas, and top it off with a moon bar for dessert! The guava cheesecake moon bar is the besssssst thing ever. Another MUST, is the green sauce they have on every table. Delicious is an understatement.

ZE DRINKS! Sangria. Sangria. Sangria. 

CONCLUSION. Try it for yourself. If you're already a fan of Cuban food, it's a no-brainer. If you've never had Cuban food before, I'm super confident Media Noche will be a pleasant surprise to your palates.
author: Noimee L.

description:
I don't normally leave reviews but this is beyond ridiculous. I order via Caviar the ropa vieja, which I've had before here as I was craving Cuban food. 

I can't believe they charged me $3.50 for 3 small, thinly sliced pieces of avocado that didn't even add up to 1/4 of a small avocado.  To make matters worse, they are added the avocado to a coconut slaw and not to the main course I ordered. Avocados are expensive but not to the point of charging this much. 

I won't go deep into the fact that the ropa vieja had very little sauce and was essentially dry pieces of beef on rice. 

I tried calling about the avocados, but shocker, no one is there to answer.  

Best believe I will go to Cuba before eating at this establishment. So disappointed and I don't think they care.
author: Danielle W.

description:
Media Noche wasn't noticed (open) when i first chanced by. later, i saw them but wasn't feeling that hungry.

drill: order, pay at counter, food comes out quickly.

offerings: vinos, snacks, cubanos, bowls, ensaladas, moon bars...

eats: Mi Abuela Favorita (.5.5)
-"guava cheesecake, crushed maria cookies, dipped in dark chocolate"
interesting fresh taste, moon bar doesn't stay on stick, just an headsup!

take outs:
-possible repeat if i find parking....
author: Victor G.

description:
If you are on the fence about Media Noche, don't be, just common down and check-em out.

The Cubanos (sandwiches) and Snacks (empanadas and such) are a bit heavy for me.  Yet between friends these can be shared with some lighter selections thus creating a more informative first timer or repeat offender experience.

At $12.50 the El Cubano with roasted mojo pork, ham, swiss, pickles and mustard on toasted bread was a uniquely heavy yet a tasty experience. 

At $10.50 the Ceviche of shrimp, calamari, cilantro and lime crowned with plantain chips was a perfect addition shared with the Cubano.

At $9.00 the Picadillo Empanadas of spiced ground beef and their green sauce was not too greasy and certainly worth the price and better still shared.

As I have no other experiences with this style of food I lack comparison to properly rate it thus I cant say it is above average yet I can say we did enjoy our food very much and we will return to check out many of their other selections.
author: Caesar A.

description:
Media Noche is a welcome addition to the few Cuban restaurants in San Francisco. The updated space (formerly Radish) is light and airy with tropical, whimsical decor.

One orders at the counter, and food is brought to you. The server said it can be very busy. I luckily chose late afternoon and didn't have to wait.

From the varied menu, I ordered roja salad; the small size was plentiful. It had a flavorful combination of quinoa, kale and beets. The agua fresca of the day, guava meyer lemon, was refreshing. For non-vegetarians, the Cubano sandwich looked great. I'll return to try dessert and other vegetarian options. Visit when you're in the neighborhood!
author: Carol W.

description:
I've always wanted to try Cuban food and one of my friends recently planned a trip to Cuba so we decided to give this place a try as a "pregame" before the trip. We decided to try: 

1. Lechon Asado: This was absolutely delicious. From the pictures, the portions looks kind of small because of the huge bowl but it's actually A LOT of food. They give an extremely generous amount of pork. The meat was perfectly seasoned and fell apart beautifully. I also really loved the black beans and rice. I highly recommend this dish. 

2. Ceviche: Good amount of calamari, octopus and shrimp. I've never had it with calamari before but it went really well with the plantains. My favorite pieces were the shrimp however because that's what I'm used to when eating ceviche. 

3. Verde Salad: I tried a piece and it was pretty good. The large is huge. You could probably share it between two people. 

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Overall, I really like the feel of the place. It makes me feel as if I was in a small Cuban restaurant ordering home made food by someones mother. The place is pretty clean and they have indoor and outdoor seating. I'll definitely have to try the empanadas and El Cubano Sandwich next time. The only down side was that it was a really hot day so inside of the restaurant was super hot. Also the music was playing a bit loud so it was hard to hold a conversation. I wish i was able to find a table outside. Other than that, this place is definitely worth a try!
author: Jonathan L.

description: I love their empanadas and guava cheesecake moon bar! And their special green sauce is absolutely​ to die for. My husband got their El Cubano sandwich and he said it was really good as well. The interior and exterior decorations are so cute as well. Very picturesque.
author: Ting Y.

description:
Ordered the ceviche and chicken cubano. So good. I absolutely need to come back here and try everything on the menu. Probably some of the best ceviche I'ver had.

Decor is incredible. The tile flooring, the banana wallpaper, the color scheme, the flamingo mural outside, the lighting, the overall vibe? So refreshing and welcoming!

I honestly feel like this place should serve cocktails. Maybe I have a slight cocktail fixation, but it just seems like a good place for a nice refreshing latin inspired drink. Maybe in the future...
author: Nikki I.

description:
3.5 STARS 

I have this one friend (we all have one of them)...

Friend: "Hey, I need a rec for a nice, new hot spot."
Me: "Liholiho but don't lag THIS time because it's going to be very hard to get into."
(This was when the restaurant first opened in 2015.)

1 month later...

Friend: "Hey, I need a rec for a nice, new hot spot."
Me: "How did you guys like Liholiho?"

Friend: "Oh yea, I forgot...I'll make reservations tonight - it's for her birthday THIS Saturday."

A week later...

Me: "I hope she enjoyed her birthday dinner at Liholiho?"
Friend: "We didn't go, it's a 2 month wait for reservations - why didn't you tell me it was THAT popular!"

This same friend is the one who would print his term paper at 9:55 am when it's due at 10 am sharp....only to find out he never replaced his old ink cartilage. Aye...

The restaurant industry is so volatile in San Francisco that you never know if it's going to be the next hot spot with 2 hour waits (or a dud that closes in 6 months) so I like to visit new businesses when they first open. 

Always wanted to visit Radish for their shrimp corn dogs but they closed before I could visit (see, what I mean!) and has recently been replaced with Media Noche, a fast-casual eatery serving Cuban inspired food. 

On the menu are Cubanos ($11.50-$12.50), Salads ($6-$15), Rice Bowls ($11 - $16.50), Snacks ($5-$10): ceviche, croquetas, empanadas, and Ice Cream Bars ($5). Wine and beer only. Cc's accepted. 

To start, I ordered the Piccadillo Empanadas: Spiced ground beef, famous green sauce ($9): http://bit.ly/2mzxCsE. The empanadas were the perfect pockets of fried savory delicousness. Beautifully crisp exterior filled with a flavorful ground beef mixture: http://bit.ly/2nPYWDn. The accompanying chimichurri sauce added good acidity and herbacousness. They also have a bottle of Salsa Picante on every table that was BOMB - wonderfully tangy with good heat. I made sure to ask for a tiny container of it so I can dunk my leftover empanada in later. 

I also ordered the Verde Salad: Cabbage, young kale, avocado, manchego, spiced pepitas, mojo vinaigrette (Large - $10 + $5 lechon): http://bit.ly/2nPNIhZ. I would not recommend it, nor would I order it again. The lechon was tender but was missing that rich, lush mouthfeel. I know it's a verde (green) salad but it could have benefited from another veggie like sliced radishes, tomatoes, or red onion for varying texture and a pop of color. The vinaigrette had lots of acidity so it would have been nice to have more buttery avocado for balance. 

I came for an early lunch so service was prompt and I received my food in less than 8 minutes. 

Loved, loved the festive space! There's a beautiful flamingo mural outside and as you walk in, you're greeted with pretty floor tiles, lots of teal, greenery, and destressed tables for that fun, beachy and rustic vibe. The bright banana wallpaper in the restroom was super cute and seems to be selfie worthy. Tables are communal and there's counter seating. I heard that outdoor seating is in the works. 

Parking...it's the Mission so good luck but make it worthwhile...Boba Guys is just a couple of doors up and Garden Creamery is just one block over. 

Highly recommend the empanadas but skip the salad and go for one of their cubanos which looked huge. And, slather that salsa picante on e-v-e-r-y-t-h-i-n-g...no judgement because next time (when they have yucca frita), I plan to wear that sauce!
author: Cherylynn N.

description: I have dined here about three times now. The first time I ordered empanadas which were okay. My main complaint was that they were too salty. The second time was through a food delivery service and I ordered the verde salad which was so delicious. So that bring me to today. It's a warm day for San Francisco and a salad sounded like the perfect thing for lunch. I once again ordered the verde salad but this time it had nothing but the middle chunks and a few pieces of actual salad greens you can see my picture for more context. I only ate about a quarter of the salad before quitting. It was so disappointing. I have now written them off and won't be dining here again.
author: Nina H.

description:
Minus one star: I had the pulled pork and coconut slaw bowl. Pulled pork was a little salty.

Big portions, I had to split one order with my friend and we still had some to take home!

Good customer service, friendly staff

Good ambiance, I loved the interior decor

Good facilities.
author: Jean S.

description: Delicious lunch whilst exploring around the city. Not a very large space with limited seating inside and outside however the food was tasty and the sangria was yummy and so refreshing on a perfectly warm San Franciscan day. Quaint little spot that's definitely worth checking out.
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
Checked out Media Noche in the Mission because I wanted to do Sunday Streets and was in the area.  It's pretty new, I went because I saw Tablehopper's IG pic and decided to go.

It's another of those order at the register, get a number, and they bring the food out to you.  I got 2 things: Ensalada Verde $6 small or $10 large - it has cabbage, young kale, avocado, manchego, spiced pepitas, mojo vinaigrette.  It was tasty enough for a salad.  I liked it.

El Cubano $12.50 - roasted mojo pork shoulder, smoked ham, swiss cheese, house pickles, mustard.  It's served super hot so be careful holding it, pork shoulder they give you a lot, but not very tasty and kinda dry, ham didn't taste any smoke, pickles were fine.  I dipped my sandwich into the green Salsa Picante, which made it taste a lot better.  Sandwich is HUGE - it's cut in half and 1 person can eat half with a salad to be full for lunch.

Help yourself to water after you pay it's in a container at the end of the counter.

I want to try the ice cream bars next time they call Moon Bars:

Mi Abuela Favorita - guava cheesecake ice cream, crushed maria cookies, dark chocolate $5

Cafe Con Leche - cuban coffee ice cream, cocoa nibs, dark chocolate $5

No Cuban coffee yet sign said Coming Soon.

You can charge your order.

One unisex bathroom - very nice inside with banana wallpaper.
author: Ann L.

description: Amazing! Love this place from the moment you walk in, seeing the decor, friendly staff to the time you take your first bite of their amazing Cuban food.
author: Michael W.

description:
Finally got to try Media Noche after having it bookmarked for so long! This place definitely did not disappoint! Came here to catch up with my best friends and grub on some Cuban goodness. I ordered the Cubano Sando, an order of the beef empanadas, & the house sangria. The meat in the sandwich was sooooo tender and full of flavor!

My friends also enjoyed their bowls & drinks. This place is my go-to for a Cuban fix!
author: Kristine C.

description:
My friend and I have been talking about trying Media Noche, a fast-casual Cuban counter restaurant in San Franciso's Mission District, for a few months now. We decided to hit up a couple of our other friends to grab brunch at this cute spot during Burning Man weekend.

As you can probably tell from the photos, the restaurant itself is very light and airy with mint-colored accents and colorful floor tiles. Burning Man weekend was the perfect time to go since the restaurant was way less crowded than it normally is, allowing us to fully enjoy the space and to take our time enjoying the food and catching up with each other!

Our brunch was super yummy. I had a refreshing guava agua fresca and the picadillo empanadas, which were stuffed with spicy ground beef and deep-fried to crispy perfection. It came with a yummy green sauce that paired deliciously with the empanadas. According to my gal pals, the salads are tasty too, although portions are on the smaller side. We will definitely be back to try their Cubano sandwiches, Mariquitas, and guava lime flavored Moon Bars!
author: Diana Y.

description:
I stopped by Media Noche for their launch week for a Friday night dinner date. It's a spicy little Cuban dig on the corner where Radish used to be.

When you arrive, you'll notice that the restaurant is aptly decorated after Cuba in a very tasteful, pastel-blue way. It's a cute spot - the staff are friendly and eager to help.

However, the next thing you'll notice after the nice decor is that it's self-serve.

"Okay, okay - nice restaurant with places to seat, nice staff, and walk up to order," you may think, "maybe this is like a cleaner, Cuban version of Garaje for the Mission."

You'll order, notice some pretty high prices for sandwiches, salads, and bowls, and wait for a place to sit.

The food comes pretty quickly - you'll notice the staff is efficient and organized (unlike many new openings these days) - in modest presentation. The Media Noche (sandwich) tasted exactly like what I expected: savory, a bit greasy, and with a tangy/sour pickle aftertaste. My partner didnt' enjoy her order as much as I, but we agreed the food was good.
 
And, if I had to be honest - that's kind of the impression that Media Noche leaves in my mind. High prices, pretty good food, a cool place to eat, but definitely don't expect any service - just don't expect to make this a date spot.

Pay it a visit and let me know if you enjoyed it!
author: Jeremy C.

description: I just had dinner tonight here and this place made me feel like home. I'm Cuban, and I haven't been in a place as Cuban as this one outside of Cuba before. Real Cuban flavor. Loved it. Can't wait to bring my family and share this experience with them.
author: Camilo H.

description: The Ropa Vieja was generous in portion (justifying the $16 price tag??), but sorely lacking in flavor. Big bowl of... food. I have few experiences with Cuban cuisine, but it's hard to imagine an island of Latin-blooded people incorporating a bowl of blandness like this into their culture. The beef brisket tasted like... cooked meat. The black beans tasted like... a can of black beans. The cole slaw had coconut sprinkled on top -yawn-. Found myself searching the premises for a pepper shaker to no avail. The murky bottles of green stuff on the counters were too hot (big difference between 'hot' and 'flavorful'). This restaurant must find a Cubana who will put her foot into these dishes. Some bay laurel, oregano, coriander, cumin and pepper called for! 2nd try here. I'll take one more swing and I'm done!
author: Tony B.

description:
Loved this little restaurant in the Mission! My husband and I were on the hunt for a Cuban Sandwich, surprisingly there's not many in the Bay, so we opted to try this place. (I still think the best one is 'Un Bien' in Seattle.)

Maybe it's because I live in the land of raw fish and plate lunch so anything remotely different and tasty is so appreciated by me, but I really liked what we ate here. And because it was in the middle of the week and the day, it was pretty empty so service was spot on/friendly and we had a nice quiet lunch overlooking the street action. 

We got the Celia and the El Cubano, both were freshly made and very tasty! It didn't look at all what I was expecting. Then again, I only ate one Cuban sandwich before here and that one was a massive, saucy, spicy beast! These sandwiches were still saucy but definitely more manageable.  

Because it's the Mission, and parking is rough, I'd come here again but would have to plan for it as I don't live in the area and it's not terribly convenient to come out here, however I see they deliver so in the future I think that'll be my option.
author: Elizabeth N.

description: Not authentic, the only thing even tasted good was the empanadas..  customer service need help too..  looked for the flamingoes and they were gone..  too pricey..  I bought empanadas and ceviche (which was nasty) and one Cuban ice brewed coffee which was 30.00 dollars.  Overrated..
author: Priscilla J.

description:
I was excited to try this place since there aren't many Cuban restaurants in the city. When we were in the Mission this Sunday I had to give it a go.  
We came in after picking up our usual loaf of bread from Tartine.  Stark difference from the line we always encounter there to Media Noche which only had one couple inside.  I ignored this choosing instead to blame it on timing; way late for lunch & too early for dinner.  Normally I would walk the other way when there is no one in, a sure red flag for me.  
The decor is cute and minimal.  Pretty tiled floor, communal tables, hanging plants.  There's self serve water next near the cashier and food is served in an enamelware plates that reminds me of camping dishes.   
The menu is not extensive which is sometimes a good thing: sandwiches, bowls, salads, and snacks.  Drink selections: wine, beer, sangria & mimosas along with cold Cuban coffee and cafe con leche.  
We ordered Picadillo Empanada ($9) Mariquitas ($5.5) Croquetas de M.N.($9) and El Cubano ($12.50).
Coquetas were on the small side.  It comes with what they describe as aioli but it reminds me more of tartar sauce because of the pickle relish.  I would have rather have a couple big ones than a few quarter sized ones for $9.  Not worth getting and taste is meh.
Mariquitas came in a bowl with their famous green sauce which I think was the best thing they had.  Thicker slices than what I'm used to and not seasoned enough. This may be worth the $5.50 but not with the hair we found at the bottom of the bowl.  Took off one star for this one. A definite not coming back here again mistake.
You get two empanadas for $9 but they are also on the small side.  Its filled with spiced ground beef and served again with their famous green sauce.  It has a nice pastry dough which is generously sprinkled with salt crystals.  Crispy and meaty but also not worth the price.
El Cubano wasn't what I expected.  The pork shoulder was too mushy and the smoked ham didn't help.  Again for $12.50 its not worth it even for SF standards.    
Overall not worth it.  I've had Cuban food for far less and taste much better like Portos in LA. I don't mind paying more for food because of overhead cost such as being in SF but at least be good.  Too many other options to come back here again.
author: Naty D.

description:
I came here for dinner and it's a nice fast casual place to eat or you're on a date or want to grab a quick meal with friends. You order at the counter, grab a table inside or outside and they bring your food to you. It's not super authentic Cuban food but it's still decent enough and I'd come back here to try something else with meat. (I was dining with a friend that was vegetarian so I need to come back)

We shared a few things:

Queso & Black Bean Empanadas ($8.50) - Come with their famous green sauce, the dough is a bit on the thicker side and it's deep fried so it's crispy on the outside. Definitely not healthy for you, but it's good with the green sauce. I'd get these again. 

Mariquitas ($5.50) - Plantain chips with green sauce - these were pretty standard plantains, you can probably buy something similar at Trader Joe's or down the street at the Mexican corner store, but it pairs well with the green sauce, so it's a nice snack for 2-4 people to share. 

Gloria Cubano ($12.50) - Crispy eggplant, coconut slaw, avocado, green sauce. This was good and a nice vegetarian option but it wouldn't be a sandwich I'd order over and over again. The eggplant is deep fried and pairs well with the coconut and the green sauce on anything is good, but overall was just okay. Next time I'll try one win pork. Decent for a vegetarian option but not amazing.

Overall, it's a decent place for Cuban food and one of the few in SF. The place is decorated nicely, slightly above average prices for the type of food, and the food is pretty good but not very authentic (not that I've been to Cuba but I've had a lot of Cuban food in Miami). I would probably give it 3.5 stars.
author: Christina L.

description:
Wanted to come to this place after it was featured in SF eater. It is very cute and is a pretty good concept, as Cuban food is pretty hard to come by on this side of the coast. The sangria is gooood. So light and refreshing! 

We had the empanadas, which the highlight was the green chimichurri sauce that came with it. The Cubans were just okay, my favorite of the ones we tried was the fried chicken one. The original Cubano didn't seem quite right to me, the last time I had one was in Miami, so I'm going to guess we had some pretty legit ones. Probably won't really be back, too many places to try in SF.
author: Annie S.

description:
awkward pro-tip: go into the bathroom and maybe take your phone/camera. The wallpaper is metallic blue covered with bananas. Definite instagram fodder.

Now to the real stuff :P Media Noche is a cute relatively healthy Cuban place nestled in the mission.  I got the empanadas and a side of the shredded coconut salad, which was definitely filling enough for dinner.  With no surprise, the empanadas were the star of the show, freshly fried and crunchy, paired with a great tangy sauce.

My friend got some kind of shredded chicken bowl and it was also yummy (and pretty healthy!). I really appreciate that Media Noche offers lots of options with veggies.
author: Jenny C.

description: I loved the ambience of Media Noche. It's nestled into a residential part of Mission and you can tell it brings vibrance to the whole block. The employees behind the counter were very warm and welcoming and they were quick to offer help if needed. The selection was decent; I like when the menu is limited so you don't have to spend too much time going through your options. The food was very good. I had never had a bowl from a Cuban spot before. It was very modern! Exactly what you should expect in SF. I gave it 4 and not 5 because, although it was good, it didn't blow my socks off like the Cuban spots in Tampa. I would recommend experiencing it though.
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
I haven't been this happy about a new restaurant in quite a while. My friend and I met up for a light dinner at Media Noche. We shared a Cubano Sandwich and an order of Picadillo Empanadas.

The Cubano sandwich was huge. It would certainly be too big for one person and it worked well for the two of us. All of the components complimented each other so well. The mustard really tied together all of the flavors. It was so good!

the Picadillo Empanadas came with a yummy green sauce. The beef mixture was well seasoned and juicy. The pastry had a great texture. It was super tasty.

We complemented this delicious food with guava agua fresca. 

$30 well spent.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Went on Saturday for lunch, order the Cuban sandwich and the croquetas. The sandwich was good, pork tender ham was good ham not the cheap stuff.  My only criticism would be that the sandwich is too thin. I'm used to the fat Cuban sandwiches from Miami and the Caribbean.  Now the croquetas, OH MY GOD THE CROQUETAS!!!  They were absolutely delicious!!!! I wonder if they plan to add a croqueta sandwich like they do in Miami. That would be to die for!!! 

The spot is super cute kind of retro and I loved it. 

I would definitely be back!!!
author: Angela N.

description:
This place was such an amazing find! Although I went with the healthier option and got the Verde salad with added chicken, their desserts AND grain bowls AND the sandwiches looked mouthwatering!

I loved the flavor of chicken and the size of my salad. The chicken was tender, shredded, with a very interesting marinade - definitely recommend!

This place isn't just great for food though - it's the ultimate destination if you love social media and taking pictures. The floor tiles are the cutest thing ever, and I suggest you be basic and take a photo in the bathroom - because the walls are all covered in BANANAS!

All in all - definitely coming back here for more food to try.
author: Marina C.

description:
Delicious but pricey food. 

I grew up with a Cuban Bakery down the block from my street, so I've had my share of Cubanos. The key is buttering the bread and pressing it on the hot skillet. Media Noche certainly doesn't disappoint. 

If you are looking for hearty Cubanos, this is the spot! Unfortunately, with tax sandwiches run you $14.50 and salads almost $18--the California hipster tax. 

I would suggest trying this restaurant with a large group of friends and sharing. I highly recommend the Celia sandwich and the beef empanadas.
author: Joanna S.

description:
Pretty cool vibe overall. Chill staff no issues really overall. Just giving this a 3/5 as I judge Cuban food and all Caribbean food very strict. I came with my family, we all tried something different.

I had the Cubano sandwich because why not. It was the correct recipe, all the elements were there but it didn't have that bakery freshness I'm typically use to. The lechon/pork was a little dry. 

My family had different bowls. One with ropa vieja the other with lechon. They both noted that the rice was a bit grainy and missing that soft fluffy professional white rice feel haha. Some flavors were lacking. Overall we were content but this place really has an opportunity to shine. We wrapped up with the guava ice cream popsicle covered in Maria cookies or "graham crackers". Guava flavor was more subtle than I like but still hit the sweet tooth. Guava like aqua Fresca was fire though!!!! 

There's some great room to grow on flavor in regards to it being a little more savory and stronger. Parking isn't great but that's the city. I wish them luck! Thanks for serving us
author: Jordan M.

description:
Worth trying once but not a place to which I plan to return.

They have some decent quality food and I love the concept for the casual place but as far as Cuban food varieties here in the states, you can do better. The empanadas were fine but nothing too memorable. Same for the Cubano. I think the most memorable part of our meal was actually the sangria. That's not great. 

Bummer because I wanted to love this place.
author: Saminda W.

description:
Media Noche is both aesthetically beautiful and delicious. Walking into the restaurant immediately transports you to Miami (or the version that I experienced when I lived there). The decor is bright and fresh; the vibe is casual yet upscale. There is a large menu board on the wall, and you order at the counter. Most of seating is communal, although they have bar seating along the windows (great for people watching). 

Their menu is on the smaller side but everything is incredibly well-crafted. I ordered the queso & black bean empanadas, the ceviche, and the El Cubano sandwich. The empanada was really good but definitely needed the kick from the green sauce. Their ceviche was probably some of the best I've ever had. The amount of seafood and plantain chips was very generous and the juice was so good I actually drank it with a spoon (no shame). The cubano was perfectly balanced - you could taste each ingredient and nothing was overpowering. 

They also have a good selection of beverages. We ordered a few different beers, but I definitely want to come back for their sangria. I also didn't get to order dessert because I was rather full, but their moon bars look SO tasty, so I will also be coming back to try those. 

All in all, this place is A+ for both food and decor. Great place for a quick meal or a fun date night.
author: Regina L.

description:
Media Noche is the perfect example of a casual dinner done right -- no table service but also no menu item over $17. And the clean, simple space has adorable decorative touches all over like a wall of mis-matches mirrors & retro flooring. 

No restaurant would be deserving of five stars without incredible eats. My friend was surprised that I ordered such meat-heavy foods, but OMG, did we both enjoy my picks. El Cubano had all ingredients in perfect proportion: pork shoulder, ham, Swiss, mustard, pickles. Every bite of this sandwich was juicy & savory. Eat it with the green sauce on the table. Picadillo Empanadas had spiced ground beef in a buttery shell & came with a different, but equally amazing, green sauce. Guava-Lemon agua fresca was delightfully unique. 

I tend to categorize casual restaurants serving sandwiches & snacky bites as "lunch only" spots, but Media Noche is so charming & serves such good Cuban food, that I'd visit them anytime of the day or night! For a heartier, "dinner-type" meal, there are Bowls on the menu containing protein, rice, beans, & coconut slaw.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
First time having Cuban food so I'm in no way an expert on what it's supposed to taste like but man, the food at Media Noche is FANTASTIC. I will without a doubt return next time I'm in SF.

My boyfriend and I split the Celia and some plantain chips with their special green sauce. I could have drank the sauce - that's how good it is. The cuban itself was tasty with the fried chicken perfectly cooked and the tangy deliciousness of the coconut slaw. I also got their agua fresca, which was a guava lime flavor that day - super refreshing!

Heads up if you're hungry but not starving, the cubans are large and the chicken portion was almost the size of the sandwich - very filling and easy to split.
author: Cara S.

description: I've had this place bookmarked for a while because I knew this was a place I needed to go when I visited San Francisco. The place is small and decorated really cute & trendy. The menu is pretty small and simple, but plenty of different vegetarian and meat options. I ordered the Gloria sandwich which has fried eggplant, coconut slaw, avocado, and famous green sauce. Then to drink I wanted the iced cafe con leche, but they told me it would not be available until around 5 (it was 3pm). That wasn't a big deal, but he recommended I try the agua fresca which was guava lime. That is an absolute yes from me, I love guava and lime so much and the drink was super yummy and refreshing. The sandwich had amazing flavor, I wasn't really sure what to expect because I've never had a vegetarian Cuban sandwich. However, I was a little disappointed because the eggplant was too tough to even chew. I took the eggplant off the sandwich and it was amazing. The eggplant was the only reason I'm not giving 5 stars. I really liked this place and happy to have a good Cuban restaurant in SF!
author: Angelica B.

description:
Perfection! 

Truly the best Cubano I've ever had. The atmosphere is spectacular and transports you to South Beach. 

The Media Noche is hands down my favorite item - Cubano on brioche. So dang tasty! 

Their sandwiches are crisp and not insanely messy! They have a solid beer selection as well. 

I come here every 3-4 weeks for lunch with colleagues.
author: John A.

description:
This place is easily the one of the most instagrammable spots in the city with its chic white tiles and chill vibe. But after trying the famous El Cubano sandwich, I was left wanting more. The pork was fairly dry, and while the ratio of pickles and mustard to pork was fine -- the sandwich just felt like it was lacking. Maybe I just need to try other items on the menu before I completely write this spot off. 

Media Noche seems like a decent spot to grab a quick casual bite but probably not worth going out of your way for it.
author: Vic C.

description:
It's a cute place.. but I can think of places in the east bay where I've had better cuban. I'm usually not a portions person, so I don't care if it's pricey for a small portion if the quality is good, but my Cubano was pricey, small, and mediocre. It just wasn't flavorful and the meat didn't stand out at all..

Maybe would come back if I needed to urgently satisfy a cuban craving, but would rather drive farther.

The empanadas were pretty good though!
author: Nicole L.

description:
I've now been to Media Noche a handful of times. The first time was a within the first two weeks of opening, and I got a sandwich. The second time I came, I got one of the bowls (I believe it was the ropa vieja).

The decor inside is very clean, and it feels like it would be a nice spot for a date in the future. Personally, I've only come here for takeout. Do plan on coming back in the future for a seated meal.

As for the food, I definitely recommend getting the bowl over the sandwich. When I got the sandwich, it definitely left me wanting for more (even though it was quite tasty). On the other hand with the bowl, I felt like I got my moneys worth. I actually wasn't able to finish the whole thing, and split it with my friend. Also grabbed a moon pop my last time here, was a treat to have on a warm sunny day. Will stop by for one of these on the way to Dolores in the future, to skip some of those crazy ice cream shop lines!
author: Rajeev S.

description:
The flamingo heart wall. That's what caught my eye about this place. But the inside of the restaurant blew me away. A beautiful shade of turquoise, different unique patterns across the floor, and chic wall decor. Every angle of the place is perfect for pictures. And of course, I can't forget about their signature neon flamingo light in the back near the kitchen. I was in a bit of a hurry that I forgot to check out the cool banana wall in the bathroom.
I ordered the el cubano sandwich, and my boyfriend got the Celia sandwich. We also ordered mariquitas. The el cubano includes roasted mojo pork shoulder, smoked ham, swiss, house pickles, and mustard ($12.50). It's one of the best sandwiches I've ever had. Very filling too and worth the money. I normally don't like pickles, but I ate it all. Celia includes island fried chicken, coconut slaw and their famous green sauce ($12.50). The mariquitas is their crispy plantain chips with green sauce ($5.50). 
After experiencing "first come, first serve" seating at another place, I'm not a fan of this type of seating especially at places with minimal seating. It always feels like survivor of the seats to me lol. There are some people who quickly grab seats even if there are people who have been waiting for a seat. It's just awkward and unpleasant when you're standing with your food next to a group who is seated and eating, and moving aside for people walking while trying to scan for an open seat. But besides their seating, everything else is perfect.
author: Kristin H.

description:
EDITED: The Media Noche team kindly gave us a full refund for our order, and was super apologetic about the situation, which I appreciate. However, as a Yelper, I feel it's important that other Yelpers are aware of our below experience for the sake of transparency.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I've been here a few times and never experienced any issues - until last night. My friend and I stopped by here for dinner, but sadly she experienced a horrible case of food poisoning afterwards! She ate the bean and cheese empanadas and was sadly sick all night, while I ate the plantain chips and verde salad and was fine.

Media Noche - not sure if someone in your kitchen didn't wash their hands while preparing the food, or if the ingredients you used went rancid, but this is pretty unacceptable. :(
author: Anisha C.

description:
Tasty Cuban food! The empanadas were so good and so was the sandwich! The sauces for each item were delicious compliments.

My only gripe is regarding the portion size. I think it's a bit pricey per serving.

Also, the decor is too adorable!
author: Jackie L.

description:
Small place in the mission that serves some pretty awesome American-Cuban food. This is what I want to believe cuban food would be like if the US didn't have an embargo on them for so long. To be honest, I was so hesitant because I was in Cuba a couple months back and the food was actually horrifying. 

This place was A-MAZINGGG the fried plantain chips and their verde dip is awesome. Also, their portion sizing is pretty big, but it does get a bit pricy. I paid for dinner for 4 and it was around 80 bucks so I guess it's standard SF hipster.

Try their salad with chicken and the empanadas and chips as a starter. It's a killer. so good.
author: Sophie P.

description: Really delicious and creative food, good service, cute interior, and yummy drinks. I loved the empanadas.
author: Joni W.

description: I really like the atmosphere and the food here. Cuban all the way! Tasty And original.
author: Belgian D.

description: We had the Celia cubano and the lechón asado and both were super flavorful and filling. Also, Matthew (one of the managers) was awesome!!
author: Perry K.

description:
Picadillo Empanadas - Tasted ok.  Did not like the empanada crust.  Green sauce was good though!

Verde Ensalata - Delicious!  Try it!  Overpriced for a salad though.  

Lechon Asado Bowl - Pork we got was really dry.  Bowl had come with rice and beans.  Rice and beans, a little bit of cabbage slaw and some dry pork should NOT cost  $16.50!

Ropa Vieja Bowl - The bowl was very flavorful with slow cooked brisket.  It too, same with rice and beans and was overpriced, but at least the flavors were there and it made it worth the $16.50.  

Guava agua fresca and cucumber mint agua fresca were both delicious.  

Overall impression was only decent.  Not sure I'll return.  There are a lot of other restaurants in the area I'd want to check out first.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Nice vibe and interior design. The cubano sandwich really hit the spot. Layers of meet, pickle and mustard (no veggies in my sandwich! yay! -pickle is an anomaly of course -) in a pressed buttery bun! It's one of those sandwiches that makes you want to get beer, or coctail, or whatever there is to drink and get non sober.
The only thing I'd think needs improvement would be the juiciness of the pork shoulder. It felt  a tad too dry. 
We got another sandwich to go and it's still good the next day, help that they wrap it in foiled paper.
author: Jenny T.

description:
I suggested Media Noche to a coworker for a early-ish dinner (6pm) on a weekday. I regret that I did. There were so many good reviews on Yelp so I thought, why not give this place a shot. 

We arrived and there were only 2 other people in the restaurant. After reviewing the menu, we decided to order:
1. Beer
2. Agua Fresca
3. Celia (Fried chicken sandwich)
4. Pollo bowl
5. Queso & Black Bean Empanadas
6. Plantain Chips

I didn't order the beer. The agua fresca was really good. The Celia was good. I ended up taking out the coconut slaw because it didn't seem to really add to the flavor and it was making my fried chicken soggy. The sandwich, overall, didn't have much flavor. My coworker is from Miami, so he has had a lot of Cuban food in his lifetime. He said that his Pollo bowl wasn't authentic and it didn't taste that great. The empanadas though...., THOSE WERE GREAT! I highly recommend you come here for the empanadas. I don't like bananas or plantains so I didn't try those. My coworker was very meh about them.  

I think I would only come back for the empanadas, and maybe to try the Cuban sandwich. Otherwise, I don't think I will be back.

The decor was very cute and the service was good, but the food, not so much.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
My entree was pulled pork bowl which was okay - I could've done with a bit less rice (I guess that's not the fault of the restaurant) and the pork was just a little bit too stringy / tough.

But the bees knees at Media Noche was definitely the EMPANADAS! The beef empanadas were HARD yo. Like amazingly good. So good that I have to recommend you go out and try them. I would come back just for those lil suckers and eat like 4 of em for my meal. Perfectly crispy outside and a little bit of beef on the inside.
author: Willy X.

description: Cutest spot off the mission with a lively but relaxing atmosphere! Had the chefs cubano and could not be happier. Manager and staff are super nice and would 100% recommend this place to anyone else looking for dinner in the mission. Can't wait to bring my friends!
author: Dylan H.

description:
After my first lunch here, I can't wait to go back.

Something about this spot is entrancing: the gorgeous tilework on the floor, the calming shade of blue (or is it seafoam green?) that runs throughout the restaurant, the festive music. While there might not be a ton of seating space, this is a place where I'd be happy to linger and enjoy the vibes.

As for my salad (a large ensalada verde with chicken), I enjoyed it very much. It's one of the simpler items on the menu, nicely balanced with manchego, pepitas, avocado, and a sweet, vibrant dressing. I also added some salsa verde to kick up the flavor even further. While the price might be a little high compared to similar spots, the overall experience was really good. May have to return on a cheat day so I can try a sandwich or guava cheesecake moon bar...
author: Sam H.

description:
By far, the BEST meal we had while visiting San Fran. We planned on going to Gracias Madre for dinner, but the wait was too long. On our walk back to our Airbnb, we stumbled across this little joint, that was conveniently located next to Boba Guys and super close to Mission Dolores Park. Thank god we did, because this place is a GEM!
My friend and I split the vegan bowl (with I believe yams) and it was to die for. It came with so much food! The flavors were so interesting and cool, and the green salsa verde placed on the tables in the bottle was amazing. The other members of our group ordered sandwiches, and said that the flavors were spot on, the meat was tender, and the ingredients were super fresh. Service was great and the environment was lively, yet chill. I love the decor! Seating was plentiful (outdoor and indoor). I really hope I get the chance to come back here when I am visiting San Fran next.
author: Grace S.

description: I really enjoyed eating here!! The restaurant itself is pretty aesthetic and cute, and the food was really good too. We got the chicken rice bowl, the fried eggplant sandwich and the plaintain chips. Service was not bad, and the food came pretty fast as well. Would definitely come back if I lived/worked around the area, and would definitely recommend.
author: Rachelle H.

description: Um, what? I just paid $11 for a bowl of rice, beans and cole slaw. I ordered the "pobrecito" bowl, which when it says "no meat" you think it'd have at least some veggies or other topping. Nope -- literally just white rice (which almost broke a tooth on some bites), black beans, and cole slaw. If that's going to be your vegetarian option, charge less. Or add in some protein. This was just really sad. My BF enjoyed the pork bowl, but it was still $16.50 which is robbery. The cubans look good but also run you $10-13. The decor is cute and all, but no.
author: Cara R.

description: Instagram bait: every bit inside is adorable, down to the whimsical bright banana wallpaper in the bathroom. The food didn't disappoint either in flavor - although the empanadas were small. The wine is rather expensive, even by the carafe, which is one of the smallest carafes I've ever seen for wine. It was middle of a hot day, so I don't mind that we just had sangria, but it does seem like a missed opportunity to play with Cuban cocktails with a menu of only overpriced wine and beer. Media Noche is a great option for lunch with a friend or early dinner with a date, but I wouldn't come here with a big group as seating is limited.
author: Cat N.

description: The food was bland and tasteless. The menu does not explain completely what you are ordering so you don't know what to expect. It's a cute vibe and has potential but for now we just give it a 1 Star thumb
author: Couple E.

description: Great place with very tasty Cuban rice bowls and sandwiches. Had the Pork lechon bowl and fried chicken sandwich, both were delicious!
author: Jon E.

description:
Update: to the beautiful person who invented the cubano banh mi: you're a genius and deserve an award.

-

Maybe it's because I haven't had Cuban food in a long time, or maybe it's because I'm not as picky as my fellow San Franciscan eaters, but I thought the food here was delicious. 

I ordered the Picadillo Empanadas and the Ropa Vieja and they were both great. I'm Brazilian and sometimes I get a *rice beans and meat* (without the spice) craving, so this was exactly what I needed.
