When it comes to eating out I really value quality ingredients, and you can definitely taste the difference here. Sure, it's more expensive than most Cuban restaurants, but this is San Francisco, you guys... 

¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Also, I should point out that I used to live in the East Coast / the South and I've had my fair share of Cuban dishes. Media Noche did not disappoint. Bonus points for the cute decor.
author: Rafaella S.

description: This place used to be radish...I like the new spot! The decor is amazing. They've done a lot to improve the place. So bright and welcoming. Fresh and new.  Cuban food...I had a chance to only order appetizers but they were good.  I got the coquetas, ceviche and empanadas. All were good. Next time I've got to try the sandwiches or rice bowls. Their happy hour menu and prices are ligit....you won't be disappointed.
author: Jill P.

description: It was pretty good. About a year ago I tried a cuban sandwich down in PR and ever since i have been trying to find something that tastes equally good here in US. Media Noche's el Cubano was good but not great for its price ($14).
author: Yéva M.

description:
I feel like Cuban food has been on SF's "restaurant wish list" for a lifetime. SF has never had great Cuban food before! But now the day has come!

Between my bf and I, we got the Picadillo Empanadas (2 spiced ground beef empanadas), El Cubano sandwich (traditional pork shoulder + ham), and Celia cubano sandwich (fried chicken with avocado and coconut slaw). Although the Empanadas were tasty, the size was pretty small, about half the size of a hand, for $9 and you only get 2. The flavor of the meat was on point though, and tasted great with the green sauce. LOVED the El Cubano sandwich - this would be the reason why I'd return to Media Noche. I got the Celia sandwich, and to be honest it was undercooked. The first half was perfectly fine, and actually quite good, but when I got towards the second half of the sandwich, I noticed that the chicken was starting to grind on my teeth, kinda like when you've cooked about 80% of chicken at home, and slice it open to make sure it's cooked, only to find out it's not quite done yet. That was not a pleasant surprise. I'm not going to complain much about it though, or bring down their review, since it is a new restaurant, and the first half of the sandwich was good. And, I didn't get sick after lol. Overall the sandwiches were super delicious, but also small for $12.50. I would return for the El Cubano sandwich without a doubt though!

The service was extremely slow - it took us about 25 mins to get our food (it was a Saturday around 12:15pm). I mean, they are new and all, so I'll give them some slack. When we asked to follow up with our food and where it was, they were apologetic and gave us the fried plantains side on the house! Sweet. Anyway, it seems like they need more help overall. The cashier is also doubling as the busboy and bartender. I mean the drinks aren't much to put together (sangria, beers), but adding on top of bussing tables and cashiering is a lot. 

I wish I had ordered the sangria - it looked super refreshing. 

Ambiance is very cute - love the bright colors, that make you feel like you are in Cuba! But the restaurant is pretty tiny, and there are only a few tables, along with bar seating cramped up against the walls. It was a very uncomfortable experience sitting in bar stools, turned the opposite direction looking for our food, with small clearance between stools and the tables next to us, and people going in and out. Just a little tight on the real estate! Plus all the customers who don't have a table yet are just staring all customers down scoping out for a table. Happy saturday lol. 

Will return - would recommend too, but wait a few months so they can get their groove together.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Finally made the first visit around early afternoon on the weekend. Lovely decoration and attentive service. Tried the Pork shoulder with rice and bean. Comes in decent size and very flavorful. Slightly on the higher end pricing for me, but certainly worth it. Would recommend to give it a try.

Looking forward to go back and try the rest of the menu!
author: J Y.

description:
Finally! A legit, fast-casual Cuban restaurant in SF! We needed a place like this! First thing I noticed walking up to Media Noche were the aesthetics. A giant flamingo painting is on their wall outside. And when you come in, you are greeted by so many bright colors! White, teal, and light pink stood out the most. The interior is beautiful and I think the best way to describe the vibe is tropical vintage. It made the experience feel more authentic. Everyone was taking photos  inside and outside in front of the flamingo wall.

And the food!!! Everything tasted SO FRESH and that is what will keep us coming back. We ordered:
- El Cubano: Roasted mojo pork shoulder, smoked ham, swiss, house pickles, mustard. Such simple ingredients but wow it was delicious! The bread was also toasted to perfection and gave that perfect crunch.
- Ropa Vieja: This bowl was big and included slow braised brisket, peppers, onions, black beans, rice, & coconut slaw. The combination of flavors blended very well together. If you like spice, take the green hot sauce that's on the tables and pour some over. This dish was savory and rich and was very flavorful!
- Picadillo Empanadas: Spiced ground beef, famous green sauce. These were probably my my favorite. I love empanadas and the spiced ground beef was seasoned so well that it will make your mouth water when you take a bite. The famous green sauce for dipping was also fresh and had a touch of sweetness. Empanadas didn't have too much dough either which is also a plus. 

Service was wonderful. Staff was happy and friendly and our food came out so quick. I still can't get over how much I love the bright, beautiful interior of the place. Oh and the bathroom has metalic banana wallpaper all over! Very fun and creative. If you like Cuban food, you will love Media Noche!
author: Chisholm T.

description:
I was honestly a bit disappointed to find that is a very trend-ified version of a Cuban restaurant. I should've known, it's San Francisco. But I was still disappointed over the high prices, especially the $8 I paid for the tiny sangria. It was good. But not worth it. 

Our sandwiches were pretty good actually, although not very authentic. One of my friends had a bowl which was good but very spendy unless you want a tiny one without meat.
author: Jessie B.

description:
I love this place! The bean and cheese empanadas are heavenly! 

The green sauce is crack sauce!
author: Bethany H.

description: The interior designing of this small hidden gem takes u to another world along with the cuisine. It's simple but it's more than just sweet. Good food, good drinks even though there may not be as many options as you would prefer. But it just makes ordering easy! A good place for vegetarians too.
author: Radhika G.

description: I was excited to try this out since I haven't had Cuban food since I visited Miami a few years ago. Ordered​ a Celia Cubano (chicken sandwich) and Picadillo Empanadas. I thought you had to wait to be seated but it's order at the register and then they hand you a number for your order. Sandwich was good. Lettuce, tomatoes, etc along with the chicken fillet (fried but not overly fried). The Empanadas were great with the green sauce they give you. It's a bit overpriced though ($20+ for the sandwich and 2 empanadas)
author: Gerard Y.

description: What's not to like in this place.  We had a regular cubano and the chef's special.  Which was my favorite?  Yea.  Both were great choices.  The service was courteous, fast and just plain excellent.  The food was hot and delicious.  Could have used a bit more of the slaw,  but that's a minor point.  The guava-lemon agua fresca was a an great addition to the meal. Hey
author: Rob F.

description:
the dindin is on my mind
but yo the lunch is still fryin

busing to the corner the menu is blazing
biting into sandos tender so tasting
pork cubano exact chicken too
order $40 pp then glutton it down ugh
scared foodie don't ate none
had an app n 2 entrees now i'm out son

skip the apps go straight for sandos / bowls / thizzerts / drank

(^_^) Celia $12.5 (http://bit.ly/2nkcBPo)
dry in a good way #tnwss

(^_^) Media Noche $11.5 (http://bit.ly/2nkq2Py)
so ffffing softender

(-_^) Picadillo Empanadas $9 (http://bit.ly/2mRgyxb)
put green sauce on everything

not 1 but 2 ipad cashiers *genius*
tasteful light decor, fun music
outdoor tater bowl but no seats
GO TO THE BATHROOM already!
author: Dan B.

description: Beautiful instagrammable interieur. Good selection of Cuban food. But really overpriced. 6 tiny croquetas for $9. Small salad plus crispy eggplant for $16 (eggplant $9!!!). Will never come back.
author: Tim J.

description:
What a great new spot!  

The location is ideal - heart of the Mission, but on a side-street so as to be a bit more quiet.....and basically right next door to Boba Guys!

The space is charming - adorable, thematic decor...but not overly kitschy...and great music.  Even the bathroom is fun - the walls are covered in metallic banana wallpaper!

The food is delicious - I loved everything I ate.  We tried two of the sandwiches - the El Cubano and the Media Noche.  They were both terrific, but I prefer the smaller size and the sweeter bread of the Media Noche.  We also had the Verde salad and the ceviche.  I would totally come back just for the salad - get a larger size and add a protein for a healthy, tasty dinner.  They also have big bottles of Topo Chico on the menu, which is a big plus :)

I can't wait to go back and try the rice bowls - they look great - and the Moon Bars for dessert!
author: Tay H.

description:
6 of us sat down for delightful lunch.
Started with plantain chips and empanadas, which were good.
The vegan bowl was great - so my wife says..;)
The meaty Cuban sandwich and the pig shoulder bowl were well done.
Recommend this place
author: Eyal S.

description: Pretty decent salad and Cubano sandwich. Friendly staff and a cool interior. Outdoor tables are nice in theory but you're in the Mission-tweaker-corridor so I wouldn't reco sitting outside. Tweakers are liable to a) steal your food, b) cough on you and give you some nasty disease, or c) drop their pants and simply evacuate their bowls. Damn I hate tweakers!!!
author: Rex L.

description: The food at this place is simple, fresh and delicious. I got the empanadas and the verde salad and it was the perfect combination of filling and refreshing. And it doesn't hurt that the decoration is on point！
author: Tiemae R.

description: A little pricey but delicious sandwiches and rice bowls. Loved the coconut slaw!! The decor is lovely.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I am so happy this spot opened up! The Cuban sandwiches are incredible and the salad is fresh and delicious. Everything on the menu looks so good - but I don't know if I'll ever be able to order anything else! 

Staff is super friendly, too.
author: Sara M.

description: Great place.  Ordered the beef empanadas Beef bowl and the kale salad.  Enough food to fill both me and my boyfriend up.  We paired our meal with a  modern ipa. Amazing meal.   High recommend
author: Alicia G.

description: Had dinner and the food was not so bad... had some small bites and some main plates. Apps we had were the bean and cheese empanadas and croquetas... croquetas were the best thing we had that night. Empanadas were also good. Mains were a bit disappointing. Ropa vieja was served with this coconut slaw that didn't pair well with the meat. Had to ask for extra meat sauce since no sauce was served with the dish. Celia cubano was not that bad, again it had the coconut slaw in it, which wasn't that bad with it. (Hipsters listen up... for a better cubano or sw hit up Tortas Los Picudos...) this place is ok for Cuban food...
author: Jay R. R.

description: Absolutely amazing sandwiches! Absolutely gorgeous decor. Love this place and great authentic Cuban food. Cannot wait to return!
author: Casey G.

description: This place is amazing. We ate the Sandwich El Cubano and the empanadas with black beans and cheese. Also the empanadas with peccadillo.
author: Adrian M.

description: Celia's sandwich is super legit and bomb. DO NOT ORDER THE CUBANO. Worst sandwich ever. It's super dry.
author: aaron t.

description:
I ended up stopping in here somewhat by accident. My friend and I, irritated by the lines at some of the other local spots, stumbled upon Media Noche just as we were about to give up. We each got one of the bowls- me the pollo, her the ropa vieja. The bowl was delicious! The chicken had a lot of flavor and I was a big fan of the inclusion of a coconut slaw. 
Similar to some of the other reviewers, my biggest complaint has to do with the price. The portions weren't huge, but I guess that's just usually the standard for SF dining. 
The most irritating thing was the "carafe of sangria". No. A half carafe of chilled white wine and a cup on the side with a few chunks of pineapple in it does not count as sangria. I forked over $26 bucks for that, which was extremely annoying.
In the end, the food was delicious and I hope to stop back in to try some more options from the menu...I just won't be ordering their "sangria" any time soon.
author: Nicole N.

description: Not crowded (surprisingly, for a restaurant in the Mission). Decent Cuban menu but a little pricey for what you get.
author: Sunil S.

description:
I had the croquetas - amazing - and the ropa vieja bowl - very good. Service is fast and the staff is very friendly. The decor is very nice and welcoming.

Tip: croquetas - the flavour was amazing and the swiss cheese flavor wasn't too pronounced, which for me is a plus. The dipping sauce was REALLY good.

In my opinion it is a bit overpriced - $9 for a few croquetas seems a bit of a stretch. 

I'll definitely go back.
author: Flora F.

description: I had been looking forward to trying Media Noche given the dearth of Cuban restaurants in San Francisco and was disappointed to find that it was just ok. The cubano was fine but on the bland side, while the ropa vieja was more salty than particularly flavorful, and not tender. The rice and beans were fine. The restaurant itself is very attractive and I appreciate they are open throughout the day.
author: Lisa K.

description: First of all, I came here to eat, so I don't care how trendy the place is. It's not a club/bar. It just looks like any other hipster wanna be cafes in SF. They messed up my ordered so I can't comment on the sandwich I ordered (el Cubano) I split my friends sandwich and it was just OK. Nothing special for an overpriced sandwich. Portions seems average. Probably won't come back.
author: Richard W.

description:
First time trying out Cuban food... let me tell you it was delicious! 
Their agua fresca was so refreshing I wanted more and more of it.
I had their Celia torta cubana & it was bomb dot com! 
My friends who've never tried this food loved it too!
author: Victoria F.

description:
I was excited to try this place because I've been craving a Cuban since visiting Miami, and the namesake sandwich I ordered was really good! I can't rate this place higher than three stars though, simply because I felt that it was extremely overpriced. I came here with two other people, and we each ordered one sandwich and a carafe of midnight mimosa (champagne + guava agua fresca) to share. Our bill was 75 bucks. The food and drink was good but not that good. The main thing that peeved me was the carafe of mimosa. It was literally one of those half liter tiny glass carafes--not enough for three people and definitely not worth $26! The sandwich--while tasty--was also very small and I ended up eating second dinner afterwards. 

I would recommend this place for yummy food, but be prepared to pay up! Oh yeah, the green sauce on the table was bomb.
author: Taylor M.

description: We came here with a couple friends and indeed - as yelp said - it was hot and new. Lots of ppl. No open seats. Good (slightly overpriced but SF..) beer and great cuban fusion type stuff. I'd come back!!!
author: Jeff O.

description: Amazing Cuban food in a really cool vintage space. We stopped by after a Sunday afternoon at Dolores park, and shared the Pollo and Ropa Vieja bowls, Celia cubano, and the Picadillo empanadas. The Pollo bowl was delicious, but we had to go back for more orders of the empanadas - twice.
author: Matt G.

description: Ordered delivery from trycaviar...so good. El Cubano, Verde Salad, and the Pollo and rice dish. All hits! Highly recommend.
author: Nasrin M.

description: I've had Media Noche many times now, and every time have been quite happy with my meal. This past time I got the Chef's Cubano, which was a hot pressed chicken parm :O I was skeptical at first, but learned I can trust the chef and will continue getting the specials!
author: Tucker N.

description:
Nice place serving Cuban inspired food. As far as the taste and quality of the food, I have no complaints (been there 3 times before and ordered different things each time). Everything I've ordered has been very good, and plenty to fill me up.
The only drawbacks in my opinion are the prices are pretty high for a restaurant without table service ($15+ per person), and that there is not a lot of space (for seating) inside. I think they could benefit from more small tables (currently all 4 tops) and pack them tighter (perhaps they plan to add more once the business appears viable).
author: Mikkel R.

description:
This place is a top notch place if you want some damn good Cuban sandwiches. My 2 year old food snob even wolfs down el cubano along with their rice and beans. 

I have yet to have a bad meal here but let us not forget the esthetics. You've got a lovely flamingo mural on the outside, gorgeous floor tiles where you can hashtag #ihavethisthingwithfloors all over Instagram and the wall paper in the bathroom is bananas!
author: Melissa B.

description: The sangria was on point refreshing, comes with chucks of pineapple.  The bowls are great for sharing.  We had the rope vieja, and I was looking forward to a cuban style rope vieja dish but didn't.  It was ok.  The decor inside is really cute and so relaxing.  Wish they had more seating available. Came around a busy time and everything was taken luckily  they had two seat and let us seat at the bar counter.
author: Abby C.

description:
Right next to Dolores park if you want to stop beforehand for lunch, or take some food to go. 

The Cuban and empanadas were delicious. Can't wait to go back and try the chicken sandwich (looked equally as good as the Cuban).
author: Jonathan K.

description:
First off this place is super super cute. 
The young man helping my family and I was so patient and kind. He really talked us through the menu with all my allergies. 
The food was soooooooooo very good. 
The Cuban iced coffee had me wired . It was yummy. I put no sugar and it had this sweet taste. Mmmmm

The only down side was they let someone bring their dog inside to eat. I find that extremely unsanitary and rude to patrons who may have allergies to dogs.
author: Whitney A.

description: Over priced and salty, the $41 for a bowl and a sandwich wasn't worth it for me. 2 stars for the guava juice at least.
author: Cynsf Z.

description:
-We ordered 2 Cuban sandwiches and 2 fruit drinks $42+tx... WHAAAT! ambiance nice decor, hip hop music ( no salsa music?) I grew up in Miami so I was expecting more traditional flavors this is more of a
Californian - Cuban cuisine.
author: S F.

description: Went for the empanadas and loved them. The sandwiches left much to be desired. Didn't mind the price point. Woulda been much happier if my sandwich was seasoned better.
author: Joshua Y.

description: Would go back and recommend to others - can't remember which Cubano I got, but thought it was pretty great though didn't love. Quick and easy, and not very expensive
author: Camden P.

description: The decor is so cute and I felt like I was transported to Miami or some other tropical location. The service was speedy, friendly and great! I ordered the Celia sandwich which was great but really heavy on the coconut flavor so if you are not a fan, I would skip it. It also came out to about $17 for just a sandwich with tax and tip which I thought was a bit much. Their green sauce is incredible and is what makes the food taste that much better (I finished half a bottle!) Good for a one time experience but I don't know if I will come back
author: Rachel N.

description:
So what to do while visiting San Francisco? I know, let's eat! I had Media Noche bookmarked and was looking forward to eating there. We specifically picked an earlier dinner time (we arrived around 5:30 on Friday evening) to avoid the line and table waiting that many post about. We did indeed arrive at the optimum time, by 6:30, when we were leaving, there was a line out the door.  I love Cuban food and have had wide range over the years. This in not strictly "traditional" cuban, like you might find in other parts of the country, but a fresh, contemporary take on cuban flavors. So that's what you should expect. What we ate:
      Roja Salad, roasted root veg (beets) quinoa, baby kale, in a yummy cumin dressing. it was outstanding and the small size is not all that small. could really be a meal if you add some meat. Don't miss this!
      Empanadas and of course we couldn't decide between the bean and Picadillo, so luckily they told us we could order one of each! Yay. Both were amazing, delicious,crispy shell and the picadillo was a standout, all the right flavors in there. At the risk of being redundant, the green sauce is life changing. Green sauce on everything and especially great with the mariquitas. Somehow the mariquitas seem healthier than tortilla chips? I know I'm fooling myself. 

BUT wait there's more, even though we're getting full! (i'm gonna say it now, we over ordered)

      Mojo Chicken bowl, with rice, black beans, white meat chicken in mojo sauce and crispy coconut slaw, that was visually very pretty, lots of different veg and colors. All the components separately were delicious,mixed together amazing. My one suggestion would be more dressing on the slaw. I got the full flavor in some bites and wanted more. Again we had tortured ourselves at the order counter over which bowl to get (the mojo or rope vieja) and one of the owners (who had overheard our struggle)brought us a sample of the Ropa as we were eating. It was also unbelievably good a definite must have. 
     Classic Cubano, roasted pork, ham, melty cheese, pickle and mustard, a perfect umami for me.  I would say maybe a little more butter on the bread, but then again, I hardly need it.
     Drinks, Sangria and a midnight mimosa ( made with their homemade aqua fresca). The sangria, considering it was a white sangria(not my fave) was outstanding. Not too sweet with boozy pineapple. Just order the carafe and be done with it! 

We were SO stuffed and the portions are really quite substantial, some reviewers say small,I don't understand it. We ended up taking home almost all of the Cubano (which I am eating whilst writing) and half of the Mojo bowl. Green sauce to go, thank you.There were 2 of us and we could have easily fed 4 on what we ordered. for about 80$ exclusive of tip. I'm not sure how many places you could do that in this city considering the quality of the food? Again, I don't understand the folks complaining about the price. I'm certainly not going to make it at home so......

Of course the restaurant space is so unique. The antique lanterns are gorgeous and the tiles are thoughtfully designed and executed. It's not a formal space and has a nice community feel to it. Completely the opposite of so many restaurants in SF that tend to look like they come from the same mold. Media Noche definitely breaks that mold. Happy customers, we'll be back!
author: Ann K.

description:
Media Noche owners and staff are disability heroes!  Staff are disability-friendly and will go out of their way to help if you ask.  They also understand not to get all up in your face if you don't ask.  

The three sidewalk tables leave a lot of room for pedestrians.  The main door has a low step.

There is another entrance around the corner, on Lexington, which has no steps.  THIS DOOR IS USUALLY CLOSED so you have to ask for it to be opened, which is a problem.  This entrance opens to a wide clear path to main dining area so it is easy to get to a table. Bathrooms are also down a roomy hall, and generously sized.

The order counter is above waist height.  Staff bring your order to your table.  The dining room can get loud if there are a lot of people.    Service dogs are warmly welcomed.

I found Media Noche to be a relaxing, easy place to get a bite, and felt very welcome.

Prices are in the $10 - $20 range for a sandwich or bowl.  There is a kids' menu with all items under $10.  Simple and flavorful food  Eat-in and to-go.
author: SF Disability Awareness N.

description:
I don't understand the hype about this place. The food is overpriced for what it is (and it is highly average). The portions are definitely on the smaller side, especially considering the pricing.

The ambience is quite cool but nothing is extraordinary about it. I really would like someone to explain to me why apparently Media Noche is a hot new place because I won't be returning to it.
author: Kasia R.

description: It's cute yet there is Absolutely nothing Cuban about this place.  Is Cuban hipster concoction,  they don't have a colada which I was dying for.
author: Miranda M.

description: Does anyone else always get the runs after a meal here? I'm not trying to be funny or mean. I actually really enjoy how the food tastes but it just does not agree with my stomach. I'm not sure if it's their handling practices or what. I don't think I can go anymore and that makes me sad!
author: Beth O.

description: A refreshing take on Cuban inspired menu. The interior is urban hip, accented by a wall of indoor plants and instagrammable floor tiles. The menu is straightforward, a little pricey but savory, so I'm willing to spend more for a happy belly. We opted for a Media Noche, tried both flavors of Empanadas, Ceviche and Pork Lechon. For those who are used to Mexican dishes, there's no hot sauce in here or anything spicy hot.
author: KeaNe C.

description: This place was excellent. My sister and I came here for lunch. She had pre-roasted chicken bowl and I have the roasted pork bar. My poor ball is not as good as her chicken bowl which was a bit of a disappointment, but that's OK. I'll be back for the chicken bowl.
author: Ro B.

description:
Ordered a Cubano and white sangria.

Like most traditional ethnic offerings in SF, this Cubano sandwich was just too...neat, too polite. The pork didn't have much flavor, the bread was sad. I wasn't really hit with any particular flavor from any one ingredient.

The white sangria was watered down and offered as a stingy serving.

The decor is beautiful and staff is great. 

How come SF thinks if it has the ingredients then the dish will just materialize?

Yes, the sandwich had bread, pork, cheese, mustard, pickles. Definitely not as good a Cubano as I've had elsewhere, even outside Miami.

And NO tostones? Seriously? Other places like Gilberth's Latin Fusion, Parada 22 have this awesome snack.

I'll come back in a few months to try other stuff (empanadas look good, curious about the fried chicken), because I think we need a spot like this, but I hope management tweaks its main attraction.

And I hope this place makes it!
author: Moids M.

description:
They really nailed the interior when they designed this place. I met a friend who was visiting from outside of the country here for lunch on a Wednesday afternoon. We both ultimately agreed that while the colors and the treatment of restaurant was top notch, the food left a lot to be desired. 

When I think of Cuban food, I think of rich, savory flavors. Surprisingly, I was pretty bored with the Celia sandwich, which I assumed I'd inhale since it was made of fried chicken and coconut slaw. The ceviche was a nice starter, but ultimately the entrees were both bland and could use a full 3X the spice.
author: Blaine C.

description: Oh man delicious. Cubano - nice meaty flavor without an overly greasy bread. Also had empanadas (cooked perfectly crispy and not oily) and one of the bowls (sort of like an elevated chipotle bowl). Be wary of seating restrictions (small restaurant) but the food is pretty portable and they have nice stand/squat areas by the windows.
author: Jon H.

description:
Pros:
Nice decor
Fresh ingredients 
Tasty sangria 
Pretty good price point
Good location 

Cons:
Way too salty salad which ruined it completely
author: Ali S.

description:
Love the hipster Cuban vibes, but not a fan of the fast-casual concept and menu prices.

Nice spot for a casual lunch or dinner, but beware, there isn't much seating for large groups (only 3-4 tables). 

We tried the Cubano and the Pollo sandwiches, and while both were tasty and fresh, it wasn't particularly mind-blowing. I thought it was slightly overpriced for what it was.

The food overall was good, but felt very inauthentic. The Cubano was okay - I just wasn't a fan of the mustard and brisket combination. The Pollo sandwich was my favorite of the two, but that piece of fried chicken was so thin! I liked the fresh slaw and bread. I also loved the salsa picante that's on every table - it was so tasty and had good heat.

I might be back to try other dishes, but for those prices, I'm sure I can find more authentic Cuban food somewhere else.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Came here for a later lunch on a Wednesday with 2 others. 

FOOD:
Cubano - classic, delicious. I loved the thinly-sliced pickle and thin sweep of mustard that balanced out the fatty richness of the pork. Well-toasted and good portion, too.

Picadillo Empanadas - super flavorful with a nice dusting of flaky salt on the outside. I didn't think it even needed the green sauce, but was delicious with as well.

Ceviche - the tiny cubes of cucumber were a refreshing touch, but I thought the seafood could've been cut into smaller pieces - better distribution of seafood bites to plantain!

Ropa Vieja - decent, but nothing to write home about. Reminded me of a Cuban version of a Chipotle burrito bowl. Coconut in the slaw was unexpected.

Abuelita Favorita moon bar - tasty end to a tasty meal. Loved the subtle but distinct guava flavor and the crunchy chocolate coat.

AMBIANCE - adorable setup and funky colors. Outdoor seating is available when the weather's nice.

SERVICE - it's fast-casual so no waiters, but food came promptly and bussing was efficient. I came at about 1:30pm so the lunch crowd had already died down, but I imagine it would be a great place to grab a quick bite in the middle of a work day.

OVERALL: I don't get Cuban food very often so I can't speak to its authenticity, but this meal was a treat and a little something different! Would definitely recommend.
author: Sijia H.

description: Great flavors and good food!  However was really disappointed today when I received my Cubano, and it was about 2/3 the size that it normally is...  with no price change.  Other than the food being a little more expensive than it should be, I'm a fan.  Suggestion, get the Verde salad with Chicken and Cubano for two.
author: Bud L.

description: Terrible service. We asked if every was in our order and they still messed it up. Tried calling but no option to talk to them directly. Bullshit
author: Daniel W.

description: This restaurant was aesthetically pleasing. It catches your attention while strolling through the neighborhood. I love that it's a Cuban restaurant because I never see any around and am pleased to say that I can recommend a Cuban restaurant to my mutuals! The employees were nice helpful and were well informed about the food and the drinks. For instance, the cashier knew what beer complimented my meal and the weather (if ya get it). I ordered the Celia and got full off of just half the sandwich.
author: Citlali G.

description: Wanted some comfort food on a rainy Sunday afternoon (happened to be solo on Easter) and stumbled upon Media Noche on my way to Boba Guys. Ordered the slow braised brisket bowl, Ropa Vieja, and a pale ale. I opted to sit outside and enjoy the rain, the beer kept me warm. My bowl was everything I hoped for. Hearty, filing and flavorful. The green hot sauce on the table is a must try.The Will be back to try the ceviche, empanadas and cubanos. Atmosphere is bright and festive but it is on the pricier side. Cuban coffee is in the works, can't wait.
author: Masha K.

description:
Awesome food and beautiful space.  

The cubano sandwich is sooo tasty and so satisfying.  The picadillo empanadas are addicting and the Moonbars the perfect dessert.  

The space is bright refreshing and the perfect place to enjoy a glass of rosé to go with the food.  

I highly recommend it!
author: Anthony C.

description:
Portions are SMALL! If you're planning to be somewhat satisfied, not even full, expect to order more than one item... At least a sammie and salad. That puts you above $20 for very little food. When the waitress brought out my large salad, I almost told her that she brought me the wrong order bc the amount of salad in the bowl was pitiful. 

Re service: if you don't want ppl "saving" tables, you could let your customer know either in a hospitable manner or like you did, completely rude and unprofessional. Mind you, we sat down for less than 2 min while looking at the menu and sharing the table with another party.
author: Scottie P.

description: 3.5 for food and price, but 4.5 for ambiance and great service, so I'll round up. I was curious about this new Cuban restaurant, especially since they had a vegetarian friendly sandwich. This restaurant is in the heart of the mission and is so charming inside! You order at the register and then they bring you your food. My dad and I shared the ceviche and the eggplant sandwich. I absolutely loved the ceviche! What's unique is that they come with plantain chips. The ceviche is super fresh and has a good spicy kick. Kinda wish they gave just a tad bit more. The sandwich was just okay. I feel like eggplant tends to get lost because it's texture blends in with the bread. Also it was pretty expensive for a vegetarian sandwich and it's not like it comes with any sides. I really wanted the guava cheesecake dessert but they had none at the time. Matthew, the server, was kind enough to compensate for this by offering my dad and I a taste of their other dessert. We really appreciated that.
author: Lexi R.

description: Being from South Florida. this is where I went to get my Midnight sandwich fix. Love the decor and bananas​ in the bathroom​.
author: Matt B.

description: OMG! What is goong on in my mouth right now?! I just had the Gloria and eggplant never tasted so good. Great service!  Clean space.  Reasonable.  Just come over already!
author: Kiana R.

description:
They have a nice start with the interior, though its not very Cuban feeling. I mean sort of with the tile but not quite. They could certainly liven it up a tad more with some paintings and music. Its hard to feel your in Cuba without some paintings or photos of old cars somewhere. I know the new thing is to be bland, but you can make something work to make it seem more like Cuba. Creativity is not just for the bathroom. As it is now, it is more leaning towards a cappuccino spot. A bit more effort in to making the place feel more like a cultural escape would do the place well, IMO. How about a giant pink flamingo extending past an entire wall? Or a giant 50s car? Anything Cuban really. White tile. Meh. 

The food: It seems like the food would be the sort you would get at a very good street corner spot in Cuba. One of those great find dive spots. Except Media Noche is bringing you this food to San Francisco in a very posh setting. Its obvious the chefs here know what they are doing. All said, I can't say that I am aware of Cuba being known for its food. All in all, its not really about the food, which don't get me wrong is not bad, and more about experiencing a culture. The food, IMO is just nothing to write home about. ...mustard and pickles is a good combo, no one can argue... However I do feel more cultured as I leave Media Noche, knowing what they eat in Cuba. ...great people...

Prices may seem expensive but its the norm these days to spend $12-14 on a sandwich. 

Overall, I like this spot; food is good enough-as good as Cuban food can be, the atmosphere is great, and the people working there are very friendly. I do find it a bit strange getting a nice plate with a sandwich in such a nice setting. It makes me miss the old mission district a bit more. That said, I will definitely be coming back, mainly for the friendly people and good vibe.

Advice: don't give up on the interior yet. Your 65% of the way there. The bland white NY tiles on the walls were maybe not the best decision, but you can remedy that with the advice above.
author: H K.

description:
Decor is beautiful. Tried the Gloria sandwich which was vegetarian and loved it. Experience was a tad expensive for the amount of food but am glad I checked this place out. 

Counter style service and open seating. This place is only good for groups of 8 or less if it's relatively empty. I went on a Wednesday evening and had no problem getting seated. 

Lastly, got an ice cream bar off the dessert menu, I believe it was guava cheesecake flavored. It was the best part of the meal and I would come back just to eat that again.
author: Shruti S.

description:
Legit. I've been searching for a good Cuban sandwich, and this is pretty solid. 

(FWIW https://www.yelp.com/biz/lechonera-latina-orlando-2 is the single best Cuban sandwich I've ever had. If you like Cuban sandwiches, and you're ever on vacation at Disney, this is worth the 45m drive)

The empanadas are delicious. Whatever their dipping sauce is (not the bottled stuff, but the one that comes with the empanadas) is outstanding.

Agua fresca of the day was papaya-meyer lemon. Also delicious.

They have an espresso machine with a sign that says Cuban coffee is coming soon. I'll be back.

Nice interior. Cool flamingo art on the outside wall by fnnch.

Mostly 4/5 because the empanadas are fried instead of baked. I'm definitely going back.
author: Tim R.

description: What a welcome addition to the mission!  Small but diverse menu with modern touches on Cuban classics. The Media Noche (Cubano on brioche) is killer! And the guava-lime agua fresca?  YUM!
author: Jon B.

description:
I tried the porkbowl. This place is super cool, staff is friendly and the food is really good. 
I recommend even the plaintain chips - OMG so crispy and delicious!
I'm already thinking of going back tomorrow!!
author: Pilates G.

description: I was so excited when this spot first opened up, but my opinion has since changed. I went a couple nights ago, and while they still have the aesthetic and cool vibe, I was sadly unimpressed with the food compared to my first visit.
author: Brittany B.

description:
Más sangría por favor!
Step 1: drink the sangria
Step 2: try the two green sauces, I'm on team spicy but both are delicioso
Step 3: more sangria!
author: Kathleen A.

description: Definitely 5 stars rating for this hidden gem in SF city. It is a small little cafe setup at the corner of 19th St & Lexington St. A perfect place for you to get a quick bite and a taste of Cuban food.
author: Siew Chin Y.

description: Beautiful space, good value, and amazing food. The empanadas were especially great, but the sandwiches were tasty as well. Media Noche is a great option if you're looking for food to take with you to Dolores Park on a nice day.
author: Manu V.

description: I got the Gloria, its one of there...or should I say only vegetarian sandwiches.  It was delicious, I would definitely go back there to get that.  They also have pastries with guava jelly in it.  Amazing!
author: Michelle G.

description:
I have been seeking good Cuban food for a while now, to substitute for some of my favorite cheap hole-in-the-wall spots in NY, and particularly for good media noche sandwiches.

This place has a minimalist but cozy interior, and delivered a pretty solid media noche sandwich! I'm not sure I've seen brioche toasted more perfectly and uniformly on the outside, and was still light and soft inside. All the usual components of a good media noche sandwich were there, although unlike a usual hole in the wall spot, was much less greasy (for me, this was actually a negative lol). Overall, a good sandwich and nice hangout spot, but minus a star for being not so great value (around $14 all in for a sandwich with fairly inexpensive components, maybe one of the most expensive casual sandwiches I've eaten)
author: Neal B.

description:
San Francisco has been missing any decent Cuban food for a while, and Media Noche totally nails it. Menu, food quality, decor, service style--smart and well executed. Hope they are around for a while, and could easily see them expanding to other locations in the city. Ceviche was fresh, simple and tasty; Miami-style Cubano was hearty and satisfying; Lechón asado bowl was greater than the sum of its (very delicious) parts. 

Another bonus is unlike many places, they serve straight through the day, so it's a perfect place to stop in for some afternoon sangria!
author: Jessica S.

description: Ordered the celia, the empanadas, and the agua fresca. all so delicious, especially the empanadas. didn't get a chance to try the guava cheesecake
author: Kaylee C.

description: The beef empanadas do not taste like traditional empanadas. The ground beef was not cut up properly so there were some chunks the size of meatballs. Also, they're filled with what seems to be raisins and grapes so they are very sweet. I also ordered the verde salad and that was a disgusting mess of old leaves with a sour dressing. The only ingredient that was actually tasty were the seeds they add to the salad. Overall, a huge disappointment.
author: Karina V.

description: I really wanted to like this place - so much so that I visited three times. I like the concept and I'm a sucker for cool decor. I tried two sandwiches, the croquetas multiple times, the mariquitas, and the pineapple sangria. The green sauce is really good. The mariquitas are good but I would have liked a little salt on them. The sangria is good. I don't like the croquetas. I wish they had more potato than cheese, and they should really be served with the green sauce instead of the aioli - something to contrast the starch and fat. The Celia sandwich was boring, and the pork in the medianoche was dry. Overall the food is mediocre and feels overpriced for what it is.
author: Kayla M.

description:
I love new places.  Chance to discover something special or something not so much...  Well in the case of Media Noche, it is something special indeed.  So a long review is what they get!  In town visiting and checking out the mission district we came across this new place and were intrigued.  Was here on what I think was their first day being open.  So of course this could have been a disaster as I have been to places open a month that still don't have their shit together.   The folks running this place know their business and it shows in both look and taste.

Great feeling to the space.  I've never been to Cuba, but seen pictures and this certainly has the feel of that part of the world.  Simple, clean, bright colors.  Cool tiled floor and vibe and of course a playlist heavy on some great latin sounds, which is a nice change of pace.

Order at the counter from a small but potent menu.  They bring you the food.  Nothing fancy but it works and is fast.  Mostly counter seating in the place and I think 3 or 4 tables which I guess are communal in style but not that big. 

So of course, had to try the cubano.  I've had many and this is one of the best I've had.  Kind of the deli sandwich of Cuba.  But with a very tasty house roasted pork and home made pickles on a perfect light french roll,  this baby toasted up in the "press" just the way it should.  Cheese was melty and the flavors were right where I like them.   Tried the Ceviche.  I am not normally a fan of this but wife is,  and she loved it and I ate it too.  Which says a lot.  It was very fresh tasting with a different kind of marinade on the fish.  Side order of fried plantains were perfect in thickness and crunch.  Killer green salsa that I don't know what was in it but it sure was very tasty.  Not spicy and a different kind of flavor, not your typical salsa.  You could put this stuff on a LOT of things and it complements the dish,  not overpowers it. 

Picadillo empanada and veggie empanadas were also standouts.  Perfect fry on the dough so not greasy but great flavor.  And the piccadillo is something they should serve in other items as it is like the best comfort food around!  Sweet raisins and salty green olives in the beef give you that very savory taste bud happiness.  The sloppy joe of cuba! The veggie one had seasoned cuban black beans and cheese and was really good.   Side of cuban slaw was also a winner with the unusual addition of some shaved coconut.  Fresh flavors, vinegar based it was great with the cubano.

Then of course came the dessert.  Never thought they would have something so good but they said they make their own ice cream and make what they call moon sandwiches. Had the guava one,  dipped in a crunchy sweet dark chocolate, these were a perfect end to the meal.  

We wanted to try more food but needed to save room for dinner that was in a few hours.   If the other items are as good as what we ate,  I could only wish I lived in San Franciso as I would be a regular at this place. I'll be back on my next visit for sure...

Ricky Ricardo would be proud and singing and dancing!
author: Bruce M.

description: A new and great addition to the hood! Stopped by for some dinner tonight and tried two different Cubanos and their ceviche. To begin, their ceviche had shrimp, calamari, cilantro, lime, and plantain chips. It definitely delivered and they didn't skimp on the seafood. The plantain chips were a great touch compared to the typical tortilla chips at most places. In addition, we shared the El Cubano and the Cecilia between us. The standout was definitely the El Cubano that had the right mixture of everything in between two perfectly toasted pieces of bread. One thing was that they were out of their Sangria which I definitely wanted to try out. Will definitely be back to try their bowls, moon bars, and hopefully the Sangria.
author: EccentricAura A.

description: Authentic Cuban sandwich and media noche just like I'd see at the local panaderia anywhere in the Caribbean. The bowls were good but not mind blowing. Empanadillas were better than mom's... Don't tell her though.
author: Max R.

description:
I love love this place. Very cute and cozy. Honestly exceeded my expectations with its cleanliness and delicious food. We had the chicken sandwich and it was heavenly. The sauce was so good too. 
I'm so excited about It that I've been referring many friends there. Will be visiting again soon
author: Dyma K.

description:
Great food!!! Tried some items at Media Noche last week. We had the ceviche which is served with plantain chips. So delicious and fresh! We also had the black bean empanadas. Very delicious and the empanada dough was on point. We tried the traditional Cubano sandwhich. It was my 1st time trying one, therefore my review on the sandwhich can't count since I have nothing to compare it to. It was good, we ate it all, just wasn't my favorite. We ended the meal with one of each of the Moon Bars. Both were delicious! Guava was my fave. 
I've eating Cuban at and am obsessed with, Versailles in Southern California. Media Noche is nothing like it, so don't expect a comparison. Although ceviche is not necessarily Cuban, the food at this spot is great. I'll be a regular for sure. The decor feels very fresh and Cuban-like. Atmosphere is causal. Must try if you can!!!
author: Claudia M.

description: I had this food to-go but thought it was absolutely delicious.  I had the lechon asado bowl and shared the empanadas and plantain chips with green sauce.  The bowl was a nice big portion for lunch and thought it was well worth the price.  I loved the coconut slaw that came with it as well.  The empanadas were some of the best I've had and while I'm not normally a lover of plantains, those chips and delicious mystery green sauce were to die for.  Really recommend you check it out!
author: Kimmy D.

description:
Good empanadas here and I like their selection of sandwiches. My friends really liked their lemonade too which I didn't have. 

The decor inside is also clean and nice. I will definitely go in and try out more sandwiches. I think this could be an interesting weekend lunch spot.
author: Rohan D.

description: I love restaurants that are open between lunch and dinner.  No one needs to be told that being hungry between the hours of 2:30 and 5:30 is not allowed!  We wandered in here around 4:30 for a lunch/dinner meal.  We split a tiny carafe of the wild hawk sangria, white wine, pineapple, lemon and mint.  Pretty good, but I make better sangria.  We did end up drinking two of them, so...there is that.  We also split the beef empanadas, a small kale salad and the media noche.  Beef empanadas were delicious, if a bit pricey for two small ones at $9.  They are fried not baked, which I don't usually prefer, but the picadillo filling inside is fantastic.  Juicy, deeply savory.  The salad was also good, with pumpkin seeds and Parmesan.  The media noche was the weakest thing on our order.  It was really small, and the cheese was not melted and caramelized on the edges, just sort of limply heated through.  I associate a reckless abundance of pork and melty caramelized cheese with this sort of sandwich, and this one was sedate and not terribly generous.  It wasn't bad though, and I would go back and try the other things and see.  The place is really attractively painted, and has counter service.  The seating is a bit awkward, mostly stools and shared tables, but a good place to come for a quick bite in between events.  Our friends met us there and one of them got the eggplant sandwich which was juicer than our media noche.  Our meal was $55, for sangria, a split appetizer, salad and small sandwich.  Overall a cute place, that I'd be willing to try again.
author: Nicole B.

description: Love this place. The lechon asado was fantastic!
author: Keeley M.

description:
There was a drought of Cuban food in San Francisco - until Media Noche opened.
Coming from Miami, I miss a proper Cubano, and now I know where to get one! We first tried the Croquetas de Media Noche, which were perfectly fried and delicious - the filling was oozing out with each bite. The cubano was phenomenal, especially paired with the mango & passionfruit beer.

The vibe/decor is fun and casual and the staff were all friendly. I can't wait to return and try the Media Noche sandwich with a Cafe con Leche moon bar.
author: Saraid D.

description: I had the empanadas and they were delicious. At first it smelled really good and I lived that it wasn't dry inside. Definitely would come back again.
author: Celeste D.

description:
I'm obsessed with this place
Great food, decor, and wonderful staff!
Though, I would skip the small portion media noche sandwich if you were thinking about buying it
author: Henry P.

description: Ordered the frijol empanada which was to die for definitely would go back just for that. Decor was real good and the guy at the counter was cool he suggested the cubano so we ordered that and the Celia. Me and my girl split the sandwiches to try both. Cubano was good nothing super amazing to rant about and the Celia well the chicken just wasn't right. It was rubbery and has to break up not sure if it's boiled than fried but was over cooked so we didn't even finish. Drinks were ok nothing special place is a little pricey would go back just for the empanada.
author: Tina R.

description: Just all around great food here. Cubano and ceviche was yum! That salsa verde is so good that I hope they bottle it up.
author: Jakub P.

description: Had one of their bomb fried chicken sandwich's during an event held across the street today. Wow! This place is really really good based on the little I've had. I'll definitely be going in soon for a full visit!
author: Zachary T.

description: Food was good, but the guy behind the counter was very cold and stand-offish. I'm not trying to be best friends with the person taking my order but the atmosphere is very welcoming. Seeming as though you can have a nice chat with the staff... I was wrong.
author: Mandy R.

description: So good. I have ordered from here on Caviar a couple times now and LOVE it! The empanadas are delicious (with the green sauce), the picadillo bowl and chicken bowl are also great. Love the slaw that comes with the meals - has a yummy coconut flavor. Will definitely be getting this again!
author: mandy d.

description: Came here with 4 friends and spent over $100...sat outside and finished early, while my friends finished eating I went next door and got a boba tea...came back and sat with my friends while they finished eating...Cashier who rang me up 15 mins earlier walks by and makes a comment about me drinking boba tea while sitting at their restaurant...I understand this probably happens frequently, but come on man...at least remember I just ordered food from you and notice that my friends are all finishing up lunch before making a rude comment....
author: John H.

description: Just came back from Miami and had some amazing Cuban food. But this place, wow, even better! Amazing Cubanos and empanadas, so authentic.
author: Nickolas J.

description: We came an hour before closing but the service was still great. We had Cuban sandwiches which were tasty but nothing to crave or flavors to remember. I would come again for a quick sandwich or snack while in the area.
author: Mitch C.

description:
Definitely a fantasy place for people who think they're eating Cuban food. One of the most hipster oriented restaurants that I've seen in San Francisco.

Yes, Cuba is in fashion therefore "Cuban food" is the new thing. While the names of some of the plates are in line with the names of original Cuban dishes, unfortunately some of the preparation are not.

The quality of the ingredients are excellent, unfortunately it's not Cuban food in preparation. For example the bread that is being used for the sandwiches is not even close to what Cuban bread is. And without real Cuban bread for sandwiches, they tasted like bakery sweet bread. The preparation of the black beans were way off in flavor and seasoning as they would've been prepared in any good and simple Cuban kitchen. Also missing are "Maduros"! How can serve Ropa Vieja without maduros!! It's unforgivable.

The closest thing to Cuban food in the peninsula is "Cuban kitchen" try it out and notice the difference in the preparation and ingredients used.
author: Lacio S.

description: Besides from the adorable interior this place was THE BOMB DOT COM. I highly recommend the tender Rosa vieja bowl with frangrant rice and veggies. The meat was so tender, well marinated and juicy. I also had the Cubans which is a winner. I've had many cubanos and this is by far my favorite in the Bay Area.
author: Eunice Y.

description: This placr was on my list for a while yesterday i haf chance to go and enjoy the food. Menu is simple, staff is friendly andthe cafe looks really trendly
author: San R.

description:
We shared one order of Picadillo empanadas, a guava/lime agua fresca, and a Media Noche cubano sandwich, for a total with tax of about $30. We've eating a fair number of cubanos from different restaurants.

Media Noche's signature cubano arrived pressed like a panini, with the brioche bread quite blackened and bitter on one side, having a strong scorched-sugar taste - the flavor you get when you burn a pot of caramel on the stove. It was not pleasant and pretty disappointing. I should have sent it back to the kitchen, but since it arrived served with the black side up, both the cook and the server had seen it, so I stupidly figured this was the way it was supposed to be.

My wife thought the agua fresca tasted like sweetened guava nectar from a can with lime juice added. The empanada was hearty, with a spiced ground beef filling that was more or less a chili flavor. The green sauce it came with was tasty.

We will not be back.
author: Deane G.

description: Great idea paired with insufficient flavor and low quality service. Although we were the only two people in line, our order took over 20mins to make. The staff was rude and uninterested to match the seasoning used here. I was so excited to get past the poor customer service and enjoy a cubano, but this sandwich did not suffice. I won't return here, buyer beware..
author: Jd C.

description: A refreshing stop on an afternoon walk. Empanadas a tiny bit pricey for the amount you get (as is the agua fresca). Worth the stop. Limited seating though!!
author: Jonathan G.

description:
We wanted to try some new places this trip, and we were just getting in to town about 2pm

Stopped for a late lunch, and very glad we did.  

When you walk in it is clean, neat & carefully decorated to convey the feel of Cuba as seen in movies.  

The food was very good.  Fresh & well prepared. The empanadas were excellent.  Of course you have to have a sandwich from the Plancha - it is a Cuban restaurant.  The El Cubano lived up to the reputation of the sandwich. Grilled to perfection, with plenty of filling.  As good as any I have had in Miami or LA.   

For the people barking about the price, remember this is SF, with the high cost of doing business grinding on everyone.  Quality ingredients & employees cost money.  I did not find the prices to be out of line when compared to the other 15 meals I ate in SF over the long weekend.
author: Brad H.

description: The Cubano is a $14 sandwich with dry pork and too much mustard! ...And I love mustard. Also, they didn't provide green sauce to go. ¿Por qué?
author: A H.

description: Came for a concert at the Chapel that was sold out, so we gorged here instead. Great vibe, flavor, decor and staff. The enamel dishes and shared tables gave it a true Bay Area feel and the sangria can't be beat, with mint leaves the size of my thumb perfect for muddling. I'll be back if only to see the sweet kid behind the counter who gave me a little extra sangria when he heard our show was cancelled. Had the Vieja and took half home for lunch the next day!
author: Elizabeth P.

description: The food is great, but can't say the same for the prices. It feels more like a fusion place than an authentic Cuban place, but the flavors are delicious nonetheless. The empanadas were especially delicious, as was the Celia.
author: Ty L.

description: Food was good ... the portion size was not worth the prize at all !!! It's a cute little place. Not much room to sit. Over priced. There are better places in the city where you can get the same taste. Great quality for less.
author: Jane W.

description: Yum yum yum!  You can't go wrong with any of the sandwiches. But my favorite is the media noche. The croquettes are super bomb. I had a guava Meyer lemon aqua fresca that was amazing and would pair well with some booze hahaha.
author: Candace C.

description: So delicious! I never had Cuban food. Mouth watering! The media noche sandwich was similar to BBQ pulled pork but without the sauce. Seasoned perfectly. I'm hungry just thinking about it! I spent way too much money but I had to try a few things. Empanadas are the biz!
author: Christina P.

description:
I'm Cuban so I was pretty excited to hear about a place that specializes in Cuban sandwiches.  But....after trying the Cuban sandwich, my excitement has turned to disappointment. I mean, it wasn't horrible but it just wasn't the yumminess you can get in Miami. The key ingredient, the meat, was juicy but didn't have any flavor. The bread was good (although it's not Cuban bread) but the pickles were sliced too thinly. You need that crunch of the pickles. And not to be picky, but the cheese wasn't right. It was a bit too creamy. It needs that bit of tang of swiss cheese. Overall, the Cuban sandwich was meh. 

Finally, let me ask a question - what Cuban restaurant doesn't have Cuban coffee? This one!! What madness.
author: CaliGirl X.

description: Food could be spicier or tangier or just more flavorful. Pretty pricey for portion. Curious about the chicken sandwich still.
author: Princess Pompom Patootie W.

description:
I've eaten a lot of Cuban food in Tampa and to a lesser extent in Miami. I've only made one visit here, so this is a quick opinion.

Prices are high. I know, I'm not in Florida, but for $12.50 a Cuban sandwich should be good. This one is mushy and lacking in flavor. It's not terrible or inedible or anything like that, just a touch disappointing. I think they need to marinate the pork more and perhaps go with a higher ham-to-roast pork ratio to mitigate the mushiness.

The Lechon Asado bowl is a better deal at $16.50 and if you're going for dinner, it's a pretty good meal. It tastes fresh and healthy and the portion size is good. 

The place looks great. The color scheme and ironwork would fit in in Miami, though here its newness and cleanliness actually works against it a bit.

Overall, the place feels like a California airport version of Cuban food.
author: Blake G.

description: Their Chicken Avocado Celia sandwich is to die for. I wasn't as impressed with their Cubano.
author: Adelle G.

description: Walked in from downtown and that was pretty wild.  This place was an oasis to be sure.  Bright clean an open.  No table service but we enjoyed nice cervasa and  appetizers. For a meal we got the new sake sandwich and the pollo bowl. Everything was simple delicious and flavorful.  No wild spices, most prevelent was cilantro.
author: Bobby J.

description: Absolutely delicious! I'm visiting San Fran from Miami and this is probably the best Cuban food I've had outside of Miami. The croquetas are out of this world!
author: Benjamin G.

description: Enjoyed lunch yesterday, yummy food! Cuban sandwich and the croquetas yummy and the bean & cheese empanadas on point! Good service, cute south beach Miami feel and decor and amazing guava  lemonade!!
author: Kat D.

description: I wanted to love this place. Looks promising. It's not... over priced and food doesn't taste authentic. Best thing, really really good indeed, was that green sauce they have on the tables.
author: Laura A.

description: Nice, clean, hip little spot in the Mission. Cool decor and vibe.3 small tables for 2 right outside are first come first served. We were able to snag one yesterday and it was perfect! Jessie (one of the owners)is a real sweetheart. The food was really yummy but portions were small and it's expensive. I had the bowl with pork, black beans & slaw while my friend had the empanadas, a fruity drink and some plantains with cilantro sauce. Overall would definitely recommend.
author: Maria T.

description: This place is adorable and to be honest I came to check out the decor and cute painting on the side of the wall. The food is good, I had the ceviche and and empanadas and both were great, the empanadas were my favorite. The guava juice is good but it taste a lot like like the kerns can juice, not a bad thing for me since I enjoy the taste.
author: Adriana F.

description: I really was looking forward to trying out this place. Unfortunately the seating situation was a disaster. We ordered food and waited and waited, other parties who hadn't ordered food yet kept beating us out to the open seats. We had to split up our party and eat at separate counters, defeating the purpose of meeting up for dinner. If you want to try out this place go with no more than 2 people. Food was good but was way overpriced for the quality.  I ordered Sangria and paid more than 8 dollars for what seems like barely 6 oz of drink.
author: Gabriela C.

description:
Empanada picante is very good.
El Cubano sandwich a big disappointment. It's about $6 overpriced. One sad thin piece of ham, stringy pork, too much mustard and pickles. Come on guys! Just because it's grilled?
author: Rita S.

description: The GF and I went there on a Sunday just after 12PM. The fellows at the counter greeted us cheerfully as we entered, which was a nice introduction to the space. We split the "Miami Party Sandwich" and a basket of croquettes and we were full. The food arrived very quickly and WAS DELICIOUS! We both felt that the experience was good value for money and the space/concept was conceived very intelligently. It was so nice to see a design like this, and the exterior mural is a delight. We plan on trying every single thing on the menu in the next few months. The ownership in concert with http://www.hannahcollinsdesigns.com/ really nailed it.
author: Drew P.

description: Amazing. Cubanos were incredible and the the restaurant itself was clean and looked freshly painted/decorated. Ask for their green sauce along with the Cubano because it pairs really well!
author: Kiefer E.

description: it was really yummy! i like how you order and then sit down at communal tables. so much of a more efficient use of space than the restaurant before. the food was tasty and filling. gracias!
author: Ryan F.

description: Fast casual Cuban food? Yes please. Great food, reasonable prices, beautiful restaurant. The Cubanos are fantastic. The bread is perfectly crisped, pickles add a great crunch and acid, and the pork is oh-so-tender. Throw on a side of Yucca-fries, and finish with a moon bar. What else could you ask for?
author: Michael C.

description: This place makes delicious Cuban sandwiches. I had the Celia sandwich, crispy chicken with coconut slaw and a delicious green salsa. Staff is welcoming and friendly and the decor is charming. Prices seem high but once you receive your sandwich(large enough for 2), you'll change your mind. Definately a place I will come back to.
author: Thomas B.

description: Media Noche is a great new addition to the area. My friends & I ordered a couple cubanos, the media noche, the celia, croquettes, plantain chips, & some beers & sangria. The food is a little pricey for sandwiches, but our spread was delicious & the decor is adorable. I wouldn't recommend it for a large group because seating is a little tight.
author: Kat H.

description:
On a recent visit just happened onto this place, that just opened. So glad I did.
Love the Cubano Sandwich.  Cool new spin on Cuban food.  Ceviche was really fresh with an amazing flavor! Everything really fresh and top notch.  Check out the Moon Bars for dessert, fantastic.
author: Glenn N.

description: The sandwiches were very good and their secret sauce makes them even better.  I thought the fried chicken sandwich was a bit dry and the empanadas and ceviche were ok. Overall nice to have Cuban 'fast' food in the mission, with chachacha starting to feel a bit dated.
author: Roy N.

description: Yeah, so, this place makes vegetarian food well. It's a religious experience having food that doesn't have meat not suck and to be perfectly honest, I cried a bit. Alcohol is and was definitely involved in the process of eating and writing this. The Gloria sandwich and the probecito bowl might be the only two entree options, outside of the delicious salads, but it doesn't disappoint. Hearty, acidic, and most importantly, filling. You can order these alongside a Wildhawk white Sangria and be on the floor jiggling and gyrating because that shit, my friend, is on point. Y'all gonna leave filled, y'all gonna leave happy, so definitely come check it out. I know I will
author: Mathew Anthony M.

description: Wow, I was very impressed.  Had the Cuban sandwich and it was the best I every had.  Although I am from Vermont and have had only one other!  We ordered the maqueritas (forgive my spelling) without knowing what the heck it was.  It turns out it is fried plantains and they were delicious.  The service was amazing.  It was the day of the Pride parade and we were sure that it would take a while.  I am not sure how they kept up with the volume, but they did.  It must be an amazing place during a normal day.
author: Christine H.

description: I was devastated to learn that my favorite brunch spot (Radish) had been replaced...until I stopped by the other night and realized that the location must have amazing juju, because Media Noche is GOLD (I've been consoled). My friend and I shared mariquitas, a Gloria, and, lord have mercy, the black bean & queso empanadas. GET THE EMPANADAS. We washed it all down with the sangria (the fruit in it was pineapples...it worked) and called it a night. Just kidding - we went to Dandelion, but that's a different review. Overall, this is a delightful addition to the neighborhood - delicious comida and, as IG can attest, the decor is, well, picture perfect.
author: Ashley H.

description: Great Cuban sandwiches. Small menu but favorable items. The green sauce is really good. A bit pricey, but this is sf.
author: Matthew S.

description: Cubano sandwiches and easy seating makes this a great neighborhood joint. The ceviche is refreshing and pairs great with the sandwich.
author: Thomas L.

description:
I mean, where do I even begin?! 

The decor? Nailed it! The flamingo mural outside is just icing on the cake...
The food? Something for everyone... and not just something ok, something amazing. The ensaladas, croquetas, bowls, cubanos, moon bars. Everything I've tasted is divine. 
The service? Helpful, prompt, totally professional and laid back at the same time. 

These gals just know what they are doing and have created a beautiful space with a cool vibe and unique menu (and everything happens to be finger-licking good). 

I will be back again and again and again.
author: Rebecca B.

description: If you are looking for some delicious Cuban sandwiches this is the spot! The location is perfectly placed in an area surrounded by other great businesses. The venue is colorful, the music and ambience is very authentic and it feels like you're in the Havana! I had the Cuban sandwich and the croquetas. Both were so good.
author: Rigo P.

description:
I've been anticipating the opening of this restaurant for weeks now.  I haven't had any good cuban food since I last visited Miami years ago.  It sits right across the street from the old Lexington.  They had an amazing vegetarian sandwich, "The Gloria."  Named after Gloria Estefan of course.  It was a crispy eggplant sandwich with the perfect amount of crunch and bread-substance-ratio, which is vital for a sandwich.  It was the weekend so I decided to go with the moonbar for dessert, it did not disappoint.  It consists of icecream hidden under a round shell of coffee flavored chocolate.  The cool thing was that the owners were working that night and told me that all the proceeds go to Cocina SF, a non-profit that helps to support women-run restaurant industries.  Seeing that the owners are women themselves, it's awesome to see women supporting
 women.
author: Rocio G.

description: I never had Cuban food and frankly my expectations were low. But after visiting Media Noche I am a fan. I don't remember the names of the dishes on the menu but everything we ordered was cooked to perfection and delicious. Interior of the restaurant us very nice and thought through, food presentation is interesting, staff is good. I am recommending this place.
author: Mike C.

description: Astonishing, delicious, original (yet traditional) sumptuous Cuban food in an extremely comfortable atmosphere. We ate at a beautiful wooden table and admired the artistic floor tiles. Normally, tiles wouldn't interest me, but these were stunning. Okay, let's get to the food. I am a Ceviche snob, so the combination of fresh ingredients like shrimp, calamari, cilantro and lime was like a little slice of heaven. The Picadilos Empanadas were so crispy and succulent I was immediately addicted. Oops, almost forgot, the Ceviche comes with plantain chips and a special green dipping sauce that we couldn't get enough of. Final tip: Don't leave without one of their Moon Bars. Very interesting flavors. And get this, they make their own ice cream. I may have to move in.
author: NEIL L.

description: Lechón bowl was generous and delicious. The eponymous sandwich was circular--like my Abuela used to make!--and grilled to crunchy tasty perfection. Service was a little flat... not even eye-contact, but maybe she's having a bad day... oh well, the food was great.
author: Enrique D.

description: I was craving some traditional Cuban rice, beans, and lechón asado so I decided to swing by... I ordered the lechón asado bowl and the croquetas de jamón y queso. Where I come from this is considered simple "comfort food" so you don't expect to pay a significant premium. I was shocked by the $24.00 price tag (pre tax and tip) but I figured it would be well worth it... the food came out quickly which was great because I was starving. Immediately upon taking my first bite of the lechón I could only think about how insanely salty it was - almost inedible. Unfortunately the beans were also bland and the rice was lacking that freshly made texture. The coconut coleslaw, however, was quite tasty. The croquetas were ok but also very salty. I'm very disappointed in the quality of the food here for what they're charging. Please have your chef and staff try your food before serving it to your customers - you're far from the real thing...
author: Alfredo M.

description: This was really good.  It was a last minute find when we were looking for something different to eat.  My boyfriend's Grandmother was Cuban so he grew up eating that type of food.  I thought it was delicious and he liked it a lot as well.  We got a bowl that had pork, rice, beans and a couple other things.  He was surprised the rice was white.  His Grandma's was yellow.  The pork had the best flavor.  It was a green sauce that was to die for. Awesome!  We also got iced coffee.  It had a good flavor and it was very strong.  They didn't have any sweetener around so if you ask they have a bottle of simple syrup at the counter.  I needed quite a bit of it but I also don't drink coffee very often.  The service was impeccable!  They were so very nice and accommodating. I would HIGHLY recommend this place.  It was a great find.
author: Kris K.

description: As an SF native, I can attest there are not many good Cuban spots, and Media Noche nails it. The interior reminds of a real Cuban bodega, with its high ceilings and traditional tile flooring, light airy open space. We had the delicious ceviche - well balanced tang, nice serving of fresh shrimp and squid, with enough plantain chips for dipping. And the fresh kale/cabbage salad with added chicken was the perfect addition. Add a cold glass of guava/Meyer lemon juice and you have the perfect Cuban lunch, esp on a hot SF afternoon! Highly recommend!
author: Monique S.

description: WOOOOW!!!! Everything is so f%&*ing good! I had the chicken bowl and Ceviche, it was mouth watering and delicious. Tried my friends  Cubanito and Fried Chicken sandwiches and it was amazing.
author: Chrisropher M.

description: Wonderful atmosphere and great food. I tried almost one of everything. Each one is delicious and unique
author: Nicole C.

description: Alright so being a Cuban-American transplant from Miami...I could be a tough critic. Where's the Materva? Jupiña?  Taste of the food is good but not really authentic. Find a way to make some Cuban bread and  now we're talking!
author: Mary P.

description: Had the eggplant sandwich, it was rather tasteless, felt like it was missing something. The ague Fresca and the plantain chips were good. Interior vibe similar to the other new places that have popped up in the gourmet ghetto: white tile, exposed wood, etc...
author: nana b.

description: If you're looking for authenticity, this is not the place. As a precursor, a Cuban restaurant that doesn't serve Cuban coffee is suspicious to me. I ordered the eggplant sandwich, it was alright, a bit on the salty side. My boyfriend had the Cuban sandwich and we shared croquetas. It wasn't terrible, but the flavors were pretty bland and the Cuban sandwich was on the dry side. The counter service was fine, but for a $40 meal and conservative portion sizes, the food was underwhelming. I still think Cholita Linda has the best Cuban sandwich in the Bay Area.
author: Vida V.

description: Omg the food is great!  I'm gluten free and the bowls are so yummy!  My friend cried when he tasted the Cuban sandwich, it was that good! A definite must in your in the mission!
author: Nicolas V.

description: Good sandwiches, great guava cheesecake moon bar.
author: dan S.

description: The food here is TASTY! I really like the look/feel of the space. I had the 'ropa vieja' and it was delicious! I can't wait to try the other items on the menu.
author: Fabian M.

description: Service is excellent! Desert is not to be missed!! Empanadas melt in your mouth. Plantains & dip is amazing!! Cuban sandwiches are delicious!! Cannot wait to come back!!
author: Diana G.

description: Excited to find Caribbean food of any kind in California. This is the closes I was able to get to Dominican food. Not the exactly the same, but it served its purpose ;)
author: Luz H.

description: This place is so great! Such a cute place, and the salad I had was one of the best I've ever had. I'll definitely be back to try the pops --- thanks for an awesome meal!
author: S R.
